Quaere ergo eas digito tuo, et ubi sentis pulsum earum sub digito tuo, illic signa cum encaustro.	 Therefore, search for them with your finger, and where you feel their pulse under your finger, mark [them] with a hot iron.
Deinde accipe phlebotomum cultellarem, et est ille qui dicitur Incidens.	 Then take the lancet, which is called the "Incisor".
Deinde intromitte ipsum sub uena in cute, donec perueniat phlebotomus ad os.	 Then insert it [the incisor] beneath the vein into the flesh until the lancet reaches the bone.
Deinde eleua manum tuam cum uena et cute ad superiora, et incide uenam cum cute incisione incidente.	 Then raise your hand with the vein and flesh towards above, and cut the vein and flesh with a shallow cut.
Et sit longitudo incisionis quantitas duorum digitorum iunctorum, aut circiter illud: et fac exire ex sanguine quantum uis.	 And let the length of the incision be the size of two joined fingers, or about that much, and let as much blood flow out as you want.
Deinde stringe eam cum puluillis, et dimitte eam, donec sanetur.	 Then tie it [the cut vein] with threads, and let it heal.
Et iam praecessit in principio libri incisio earum, et ipsarum cauterizatio.	 And now the incision of them has been completed at the beginning of the book, and their cauterization [follows].
¶ De phlebotomia duarum Arteriarum in timporibus.	 Chapter on the phlebotomy of two Arteries in Time.
Duarum uero Arteriarum quae sunt in duobus timporibus phlebotomiae iuuamentum, est ad hemigraneam antiquam: et sodam prauam, et obtalmiam assiduam: et cursum superfluitatum effusarum acutarum ad oculos.	 The phlebotomy of the two arteries which are in the two times [periods] is beneficial for the old hemigraine, and the sodium pressing, and the obtalmia continuous: and for the course of discharges sharp to the eyes.
Et qualitas phlebotomandi eas est secundum quod narro tibi.	 And the manner of performing the phlebotomy [on them] is as I have told you.
Stringat infirmus collum suum multum, donec appareant duae uenae sensui apparitione manifesta: et demonstretur pulsus earum sub digito tuo.	 Let the sick man tighten his neck much until two veins appear to the sensation with a clear manifestation: and let their pulse be shown under your finger.
Tunc enim signa cum encaustro.	 Then mark them with hot iron [or a cautery].
Deinde eleua cutem desuper uenam ad superiora cum digito tuo indice, et intromitte phlebotomum incidentem desubtus, et eleua uenam ad superiora.	 Then raise the skin above the vein towards above with your finger as an index, and insert the lancet from below, and raise the vein towards above.
Et incide eam, sicut fecisti in duabus uenis aliis: et fac currere ex sanguine secundum quantitatem necessitatis tuae.	 And cut it [the vein] as you did with the two other veins: and let as much blood flow out according to your need.
Deinde solue coartationem infirmi, et pone digitum tuum super uenam hora una.	 Then unclog the obstruction of the sick [person], and place your finger on the vein at the hour one.
Postea pone super ipsam cotum et puluillos, et stringe ipsum desuper constrictione forti: et dimitte ipsam, donec sanetur.	 Then place over it [the wound] and small linen cloths, and bind it from above with strong constraint; and let it be until it heals.
Et iam praecessit rememoratio earum, et ipsarum incisio, et earum extractio in principio libri.	 And now the remembrance of them [the wounds], and their cutting, and their removal, has passed; and at the beginning of the book is the incision of the hernia.
¶ De phlebotomia uenae frontis post phlebotomiam Cephalicae.	 Chapter on the venesection of the forehead after the venesection of the head.
Iuuamentum uero phlebotomiae uenae frontis est post phlebotomiam Cephalicae, ad aegritudines faciei antiquas: et ad hemigraneam, et rubedinem: et ulcera foeda.	 However, the remedy for venesection of the forehead vein is after the venesection of the head, for the old diseases of the face; and for the hemicrania, and redness; and for foul ulcers.
Et qualitas phlebotomiae eius est, secundum quod narro tibi.	 And the quality of this venesection is as I have told you.
Coartet infirmus collum suum cum uitta, donec appareat uena.	 The sick man binds his neck with a bandage until the vein appears.
Deinde accipe instrumentum quod nominatur Fossorium.	 Then take the instrument called "Fossorium".
Cuius haec est forma.	 This is its form.
Pone acumen eminens quod est in capite Fossorii super ipsam uenam, et percute super ipsum cum pectine, aut cum re alia in modo eius: et dimitte sanguinem currere secundum quantitatem quam uis.	 Place the sharp point that is at the head of the Fossorium on the vein, and strike upon it with a pick or another similar tool in this manner; and let the blood run out according to the amount you wish.
Deinde solue perforationem infirmi, et stringe eam, donec sanetur.	 Then unclog the perforation of the sick [person], and bind it until it heals.
Et quandoque aperitur cum phlebotomo lato.	 And sometimes it is opened with a wide venesection.
Verumtamen non oportet, ut sit phlebotomus acutae extremitatis, sicut reliqui phlebotomi, imo sit latae extremitatis.	 Nevertheless, it should not be a sharp venesection, as the other venesections, rather it should be wide.
Et phlebotoma eam secundum transuersionem: quoniam os est propinquum: et fortasse in eo frangetur phlebotomus quando est subtilis.	 And the venesection is transverse, because the bone is near; and perhaps the venesection will be broken when it is sharp.
¶ De phlebotomia Venarum in duobus Lachrymalibus.	 Chapter on the venesection of the veins in the two tear ducts.
Iuuamentum autem duarum Venarum quae sunt in duobus Lachrymalibus duorum oculorum, est ad oculum ex scabie et rubedine: et sebel in oculo, et aegritudinibus faciei.	 However, the remedy for the two veins which are in the two tear ducts of the two eyes is for the eye from scabies and redness; and for inflammation in the eye, and diseases of the face.
Et qualitas phlebotomiae earum est, ut stringat infirmus collum suum cum uitta.	 The quality of bloodletting for them is to tighten the sick man's neck with a lint bandage.
Deinde phlebotoma eas: et tu sis stans super caput eius.	 Then, do the bloodletting and you stand above his head.
Et fiat phlebotomia secundum transuersum ad longitudinem parum, cum phlebotomo paruo, lato parumper, nam in loco non est caro.	 Make the bloodletting oblique, not long, with a small lancet, wide slightly, for there is no flesh at that place.
Si enim phlebotomus est subtilis extremitatis, fortasse frangitur.	 If the bloodletter is subtle at the end, it may break.
Deinde fac currere ex sanguine quantum est tibi necesse.	 Then let it run out from his blood as much as is necessary for you.
Et pone super eas cotum, et stringe eas nocte una, et solue eas.	 Place a pot beneath them and tighten them at night, and loosen them.
¶ De phlebotomia uenarum Nasi.	 On the bloodletting of the veins of the nose.
Venae autem Nasi phlebotomia, est conferens ad febrem acutam, et sodam uehementem, et aegritudines faciei, sicut hemigraneam, et rubedinem quae accidit in facie: praecipue quando est antiqua.	 The veins of the nose, when bloodletting, are for acute fever and violent sickness of the face, such as hemigraine and redness that occurs on the face; especially when it is old.
Et qualitas phlebotomiae eius est, ut stringat infirmus collum suum.	 The quality of bloodletting in this case is to tighten the sick man's neck.
Deinde tene nasum eius manu tua sinistra, et accipe phlebotomum subtilem, longum: et fige eum in medio leporis ipsius, inter illud quod distinguit nasum secundum rectitudinem.	 Then hold his nose with your left hand and take a sharp, long lancet; and prick it in the middle of the septum, between that which separates the nose in its straightness.
Quoniam uena non apparet sensui illic, et quia sanguis incipit fluere statim.	 Because the vein is not visible there, and because blood begins to flow immediately.
Et oportet, ut ultimes manum tuam cum phlebotomo parumper: et facias currere ex sanguine secundum necessitatem tuam.	 And it is necessary that you hold the end of your hand slightly with the lancet; and let blood flow according to your need.
Deinde liga ipsam nocte una.	 Then tie it up at night.
Ipsa enim restauratur uelociter.	 It heals quickly by itself.
¶ De phlebotomia uenarum Guidegi.	 On the bloodletting of the veins of the cheek.
Duarum uero Guidegi phlebotomiae iuuamentum, est ad constrictionem anhelitus, et incaeptionem leprae, et aegritudines melancholicas, et impetiginem et ulcera mala, et corrodentibus, id est, herpetibus estiomenis.	 The bloodletting of the two veins of the cheek is beneficial for constricting cough, and the beginning of leprosy, and melancholic afflictions, and impetigo and bad ulcers, and corrosive, that is, herpes or skin sores.
Et qualitas phlebotomiae earum est ut stringat infirmus sub utrisque in collo suo cum ligamento: et stet artifex super caput infirmi, et infirmus sit sedens super sedem.	 And the quality of phlebotomy is that it binds the sick person under both his neck with a bandage: and the craftsman stands over the head of the sick, and the sick one sits on a chair over a seat.
Deinde phlebotoma uenam ad longitudinem phlebotomia ampla parumper.	 Then the phlebotomy vein is taken to the length of the vein, somewhat narrowly.
Deinde extrahe ex sanguine quantitatem temperatam, aut secundum illud quod uides ex necessitate quae est ad illud.	 Then take out a measured quantity of blood, or according to what you see due to necessity that is for it.
Deinde fac similiter de uena alia.	 Then do the same with another vein.
Postea solue ligamentum, et stringe duas uenas strictura media: ut non praefocetur infirmus.	 Then untie the bandage, and bind two veins tightly together: so that the sick person does not bleed to death.
Et dimitte eam usque mane.	 And let it be until morning.
Sanatur enim uulnus.	 A wound heals.
¶ De phlebotomia uenarum Algeberich.	 On the phlebotomy of veins, Alzahraki.
Venae autem Algeberich phlebotomiae iuuamentum est: quia confert ad alcolam in ore, et corruptionem gingiuae: et ulcera mala: et fissuras labiorum, et ulcera mala, etiam quae sunt in naso, et in circumitu eius.	 Veins, according to Alzahraki, are useful for phlebotomy because they help with alcohol in the mouth, and corruption of teeth: and sores, bad ulcers, fissures of lips, ulcers themselves, even those that are on the nose and around it.
Et qualitas phlebotomiae earum est, ut facias sedere infirmum coram te: et stringe collum eius cum uitta.	 And the quality of phlebotomy is that you make the sick person sit in front of you: and bind his neck with a bandage.
Deinde reuolue labium eius, et aspice ad duas uenas: quarum una est a dextera labii, et secunda a sinistra eius: et demonstratio utriusque est per nigredinem ambarum.	 Then roll back his lip, and look at the two veins: one of which is on the right side of the lip, and the second on its left; and the demonstration of both is shown by their blackness.
Et illud uerum est: quia in circumitu earum sunt uenae minutae, nigrae.	 And that is true because there are small, black veins around them.
Incide ergo utramque incisione incidente.	 Cut therefore both with an incision.
Si autem dubitatio est super te, et non scis quae earum est: tunc intende ad incisionem maioris earum, et ipsarum manifestiorem.	 If there is doubt on you and you do not know which of them it is: then turn to the larger incision, and it will be more evident.
Et similiter fac de duabus uenis quae sunt in labio superiore: et plurimum quidem currit consuetudo cum eo: et incide duas uenas quae sunt in labio inferiori.	 And do the same with the two veins that are in the upper lip: and most of all, the custom is to do so: and cut the two veins that are in the lower lip.
¶ De phlebotomia Venae sub lingua post Cephalicae phlebotomiam.	 On phlebotomy: The vein under the tongue after cephalic phlebotomy.
Duarum uero Venarum quae sunt sub lingua phlebotomiae iuuamentum: est, quod phlebotomia Cephalicae est ad praefocationes quae sunt in gutture, et aegritudinem uuulae, et aegritudines oris.	 From two veins which are under the tongue, phlebotomy is beneficial: one, because phlebotomy of the cephalic vein is for afflictions that are in the throat, and for throat pain, and for mouth pain.
Et qualitas phlebotomandi eas est, ut sedeat infirmus inter manus tuas coram sole: et eleualinguam eius, et aspice sub lingua a latere eius uno uenam, et a latere eius alio uenam: et color utriusque decliuis ad nigredinem.	 And the quality of phlebotomizing them is that the sick person should sit in front of you by the sun, and clean his mouth, and look under his tongue from one side, and from the other side a vein, and from the other side another vein: and the color of both declines to blackness.
Phlebotoma ergo utramque: et custodi, ne ultimes manum tuam in phlebotomando eas.	 So, phlebotomize both (veins): and be careful, not to wound your hand while phlebotomizing them.
Nam sub eius sunt arteriae, et fortasse accidet fluxus sanguinis ex illis arteriis.	 Because under his are arteries, and perhaps there will be a flow of blood from these arteries.
¶ De tribus Venis in cubito.	 On three veins at the elbow.
Venae autem tres quae phlebotomantur in cubito, sunt in quarum phlebotomia cucurrit consuetudo in omnibus hominibus.	 The three veins which are phlebotomized at the elbow, are those whose phlebotomy has run into custom among all men.
Et phlebotomia earum fit secundum duos modos.	 And phlebotomy of them is done according to two modes.
Aut pungendo cum phlebotomo myrtino lato: aut oliuari ad subtilitatem decliui: aut secando cum phlebotomo cultellari, et est Alnesil.	 Or piercing with a broad-bladed phlebotome (myrtine), or oiling to the point of disappearing (oliuari), or cutting with a sharp phlebotome (cultellare) and it is called Alnesil.
Et haec est forma eius.	 And this is its form.
Sic Alnesil est, quod conuenit ad sectionem.	 So, Alnesil is that which comes to a cut (section).
Et ex eis sunt species latae, et subtiles secundum amplitudinem uenarum et stricturam earum Forma phlebotomi myrtini sit lata, sicut uides.	 And from them there are broad and narrow forms according to the width of the veins and their constriction. The form of a phlebotome (myrtine) should be broad, as you see.
Et conuenit ad aperiendas uenas concauas, plenas, procedentes, apparentes, grossas, et illas quae continent sanguinem grossum, turbidum.	 And it is appropriate to open curved, full, proceeding, visible, thick veins and those that contain thick, turbid blood.
Et iste phlebotomus est minoris latitudinis, et subtilioris extreminatis.	 This phlebotomist is of lesser width and more subtle in cuts.
Et conuenit ad phlebotomiam uenarum subtilium, quae continent sanguinem subtilem citrinum	 It suits phlebotomy of delicate veins that contain subtle, lemon-colored blood.
¶ De phlebotomia Basilicae.	 [Paragraph] On the Phlebotomy of the Basilica.
Basilicae autem quae est una harum trium uenarum phlebotomiae iuuamentum est.	 The phlebotomy of the Basilica, which is one of these three veins, is beneficial.
Quia extrahit sanguinem ex aegritudinibus, quae sunt sub gutture et collo, ex eo quod sequitur pectus, et uentrem: et conuenit phlebotomatori cum phlebotomat eam, ut caueat, et sit super timorem ex ea nam sub ea est arteria.	 Because it draws blood from ailments that are below the neck and follow the chest and abdomen; therefore, the phlebotomist should be careful about this one, for beneath it is an artery.
Si ergo errat, et addit in punctura phlebotomi, incidet illam arteriam, et accidet fluxus sanguinis.	 If [the phlebotomist] should err and add to the puncture of the phlebotomy, he will cut that artery, and there will be a flow of blood.
Quapropter oportet, ne phlebotomet eam cum phlebotomo pungente: imo sit secans cum Alnesil.	 Therefore, it is necessary that the phlebotomist not cut that [vein] while the phlebotomist punctures; rather, it should be cut by Alnesil.
Quod si non apparet Basilica apparitione manifesta, tunc oportet, ut alienes ipsam, et permuteris ad aliam, aut quaeras aliquem ramum eius: aut phlebotomes loco eius Funem brachii.	 If the Basilica does not appear in a clear manifestation, then it is necessary that you change it yourself or look for another [vein] or one of its branches; or use the arm as a substitute for the phlebotomy.
Ipsa enim est manifesta, et seca eam cum phlebotomo Anesil, sicut diximus.	 It is clear itself, and Alnesil cuts it with the phlebotomist, as we said.
Si autem uis phlebotomiam ipsius eiusdem, tunc oportet ante stricturam brachii, ut tangas locum, donec cognoscas locum pulsus.	 If you wish to perform the phlebotomy of that [vein], then it is necessary before tightening the arm to touch the place, until you recognize the place pulsed.
Deinde signa super locum cum encaustro, postea brachium, et seca uenam sectione concaua cum phlebotomo Alnesil, sicut diximus.	 Then mark the place with hot iron, then tighten the arm, and cut the vein with the concave incision with Alnesil the phlebotomist, as we said.
Et caue ne cadat percussio per spacium a loco arteriae.	 And be careful that the puncture does not fall into the space from the place of the artery.
Et quando uides, cum tu stringis ligamen, inflationem in loco quem signasti cum encaustro, tunc illa inflatio est inflatio arteriae: deuita ergo eam.	 And when you see, as you tighten the ligament, inflation in the place that you marked with hot iron, then that inflation is the inflation of an artery; therefore, avoid it.
Quod si uides sanguinem apud phlebotomiam salire, sicut urina pueri, et est sanguis subtilis, rubeus: tunc scias, quia est ex sanguine arteriae.	 If you see blood rising at venesection, like the urine of a boy, and it is subtle, red: then you know, it is from the blood of an artery.
Tunc ergo propera, et pone digitum tuum super ipsum spacio longo, deinde aufer digitum tuum.	 Therefore, hurry up, and place your finger over it at a long distance, then withdraw your finger.
Si ergo abscinditur sanguis (multotiens namque abscinditur) tunc stringe brachium, et dimitte ipsum: et caueat infirmus a motione eius: et sit super timorem eius.	 If the blood is cut off (for it is often cut off), then tie the arm and let it be: and beware that the weak do not move it: and be afraid of it.
Et non moueat ipsum diebus aliquot, donec sanetur.	 And do not move it for several days until it heals.
Si autem non abscinditur sanguis, et uincit te: et non est tibi praesens in momento tuo medicina, tunc incide arteriam, si apparet tibi.	 If the blood is not cut off, and it overwhelms you, and there is no medicine present with you in the moment, then cut the artery if it appears to you.
Nam extremitates eius contrahuntur, et abscinditur sanguis.	 For its ends contract, and the blood is cut off.
Aut accipe corticem fistici, et finde eum: accipe medietatem unam, et stringe eam super locum uenae strictura decenti, cum ligamento et puluillis usque ad diem alium.	 Or take the bark of a fig-tree, and fold it: take one half, and tie it over the place where the vein is constricted, with a ligature and powder until another day.
Tunc si abscinditur sanguis, est bonum.	 Then if the blood is cut off, it is good.
Et si non: tunc cura ipsum cum eo cuius praecessit rememoratio ex loco puluerum abscindentium fluxum sanguinis: et abscisio sanguinis eius non est difficilis in pluribus dispositionibus, propter locum paruum uulneris, et possibilitatem ligamenti ex brachio.	 And if not: then treat it with the memory of the place from which the dust removes the flow of blood: and the cutting off of the blood of this one is not difficult in several dispositions, because of the small size of the wound and the possibility of a ligature from the arm.
¶ De phlebotomia uenae Fuscae.	 Chapter on venesection of the vein of the arm.
Venae autem Fuscae phlebotomiae iuuamentum est, quod trahit sanguinem ex superiori parte capitis, et inferiore corporis: propterea, quia est composita ex ramo Basilicae, et ramo Cephalicae, sicut diximus.	 The vein of the arm is beneficial for venesection because it draws blood from the upper part of the head and the lower part of the body; therefore, since it is composed of a branch of the basilica vein and a branch of the cephalic vein, as we said.
Et conuenit phlebotomanti eam, ut sit super timorem ex phlebotomia eius, nam sub ea est neruus.	 And it is convenient for the venesectionist that it be above fear from venesection of it, because a nerve is under it.
Si ergo addit in punctura phlebotomi, et inuenit neruum, accidit in ea stupor, et difficilis fit sanatio eius, et fortasse non sanatur penitus.	 If therefore a nerve is struck during phlebotomy (bloodletting), and it causes a fainting spell, its healing becomes difficult, and it may not heal completely.
Et iste neruus multotiens apparet sensui.	 And this nerve often appears to sensation.
Si autem occultatur in quibusdam hominibus, et est subtilis, et non ostenditur: tunc oportet ut ponas phlebotomiam tuam qua eam phlebotomas, sectionem cum Alnesil, et deuita neruum cum fortitudine tua.	 If, however, it is concealed in some people and is subtle and not visible: then you must place your bloodletting instrument where it can reach the nerve, and make an incision with the Alnesil (an instrument used for bloodletting), avoiding the nerve with all your strength.
Quod si uena est inter duos neruos, tunc finde uenam in longitudine.	 If a vein is between two nerves, then you should make an incision along its length.
¶ De uena Cephalica.	 Chapter on the Cephalic Vein.
Phlebotomiae autem uenae Cephalicae iuuamentum est, quia attrahit sanguinem ex capite, et confert ad aegritudines oculorum.	 The bloodletting of the Cephalic Vein is beneficial, because it draws blood from the head and contributes to eye problems.
Et oportet in hac uena proprie, si uis, ut phlebotomes eam pungendo cum phlebotomo oliuari, aut cum phlebotomo myrtino: quoniam est saluior uenarum omnium, quoniam non est subea arteria, neque neruus.	 And it is appropriate to do bloodletting in this vein with a lancet coated with olive oil or myrtle oil, because it is the safest of all veins, as it is neither an artery nor a nerve.
Verumtamen conuenit tibi apud phlebotomiam, ut deuites cum phlebotomo caput lacerti tantum, et quaeras locum leniorem: et non nocet ei, si non inuenitur cum percussione prima, ut iteretur super eam cum phlebotomia aliquotiens.	 Nevertheless, it is advisable for you during bloodletting to avoid the head and shoulder area entirely, and to find a more gentle spot: and it will not harm if the initial strike does not hit the vein, provided that you return to the same spot with bloodletting on several occasions.
Verumtamen fortasse apostematur in quibusdam hominibus quando non phlebotomatur in percussione prima, sed non nocet ei illud apostema in aliquo.	 Nevertheless, it may be necessary to strike the vein again in some people when it is not struck during the initial bloodletting, but such a swelling will not harm them.
¶ De utilitate Phlebotomiae, et cautelis in ea obseruandis.	 Chapter on the usefulness of Bloodletting and Cautions to be Observed.
Qualitas autem Phlebotomiae, et accidentia eius ex ea, in cuius rectificatione oportet te cogitare.	 The nature and accidents of bloodletting, and the remedy for them, which you should consider when practicing it.
Primum ergo illius est de quo oportet ut scias, quod phlebotomia non administratur, nisi in conseruatione sanitatis, et perseuerantia eius, et cautela ab aduentu aegritudinum.	 First, you should know that bloodletting is not administered except in the preservation of health and its continuation, and as a precaution against the onset of illness.
Et ut fiat phlebotomia in una uenarum trium quae sunt in cubito, scilicet Cephalica, et Fusca, et Basilica.	 And it shall be done venesection on one of the three veins that are in the elbow, namely, the Cephalic, the Flexor Tendon (Fusca), and the Basilic.
Et ut fiat phlebotomia in principio Veris super ieiunium, in uere, et aestate: et autumno, et hyeme post comestionem, quando apparent significationes repletionis.	 And it shall be done venesection at the beginning of Spring after a fast, and in truth (Summer), and autumn, and winter after food consumption, when signs of congestion appear.
Et fiat phlebotomia in die primo, aut in tertio, postquam praeterierint de die tres horae.	 Venesection shall be done on the first or third day, after three hours have passed since the previous day.
Phlebotomia autem quae administratur in aegritudinibus, non habet horam determinatam: sed quando prouocat conuenientia et necessitas ad illud, in nocte, aut die, et in omni hora, et in omni tempore.	 Venesection which is given for illness, has no specific hour; but when it is convenient and necessary for that purpose, at night or day, and in any hour, and at any time.
Et non oportet, ut phlebotomentur pueri, donec ueniant super eos quatuordecim anni.	 It is not appropriate to venesection of children until they have reached fourteen years of age.
Neque phlebotometur mulier praegnans, nisi a mense quarto usque ad septimum.	 Women who are pregnant shall not be subjected to venesection from the fourth month until the seventh.
Neque phlebotomentur senes, qui iam pertransierunt sexaginta annos.	 Elderly people, who have already passed sixty years, shall not be subjected to venesection.
Cum ergo aliquis uult phlebotomari propter quemcumque modum sit: oportet, ut mundificet intestina sua ante phlebotomiam cum clisteri leni, si in eis est stercus multum retentum: ut non attrahant uenae apud phlebotomiam ex intestinis superfluitates putridas nocentes membris principalibus.	 When someone wishes to be subjected to venesection for any reason, it is necessary that they clean their bowels before the venesection with a soft enema, if there is much retained fecal matter in them; so as not to attract veins during the venesection from intestinal superfluidities harmful to the main organs.
Neque phlebotometur patiens toctina, id est, satietatem nauseatiuam: neque crapulatus, neque euadens ab ebrietate, donec remoueatur illud ab eis.	 Patients who are affected by indigestion (toctina), that is, the satiety of nausea; nor those who are hungover (crapulatus), nor those who are coming down from drunkenness, until that has been removed from them.
Neque infirmus cum hydropisi.	 A patient with dropsy shall not be subjected to venesection.
Et caueatur phlebotomia iterum post colicam passionem, et uomitum, et fluxum uentris, et multiplicationem coitus, et laboris, et exercitii, et uigiliarum, et ieiunii, et omnis quod dissoluit uirtutem ex re corporea aut animali.	 Venesection shall be done with caution after a colic attack, vomiting, diarrhea, multiplying coitus (sexual intercourse), labor, exercise, insomnia, fasting, and everything that dissolves the virtue of the body or an animal.
Deinde considera in subtilitate humorum ante illud, si sanguis est grossus cum cibis et potibus, et medicinis: si possibile est ei illud.	 Then consider, in the subtlety of humors before that, if blood is thick with foods and drinks, and medicines; if it can be done to him.
Deinde introeat balneum, si non prohibet ipsum aliquid: aut exercitetur aliquo exercitio, ut subtilietur sanguis.	 Enter the bath, if it does not forbid him something: or exercise with some exercise, so that the blood becomes subtle.
Et pone phlebotomiam eius in pectore, circa tertiam diei, sicut diximus: et conare, ut euacuetur pectus eius illa die ex omnibus accidentibus animalibus malis: sicut angustia, et ira, et timor: et ex omnibus accidentibus corporeis, sicut labor, et poena, et superfluicoitus, et illis similia.	 And place phlebotomy on his chest, about the third day, as we said; and strive to evacuate his chest that same day with all kinds of bad events: such as anxiety, anger, fear; and with all kinds of bodily afflictions, such as labor, punishment, excess, and similar things.
Et sedi suae faciat esse praesentes res cum quarum usu cucurrit consuetudo hominum ex aromaticitate, et odoramento, et tripudio et similibus illis per quantitatem possibilitatis.	 And let him sit with those things present that are used in the custom of humans from their aromaticity, and from their smell, and from their joy and similar things according to the possibility of quantity.
Deinde sedeat phlebotomator super puluinari, quod sit altius quam puluinar phlebotomandi: postea extrahat brachium suum, et fricet ipsum phlebotomator manu sua bis, aut ter.	 Then let the phlebotomist sit on the stool that is higher than the stool for phlebotomy; then he will withdraw his arm and rub it twice or thrice with his hand.
Deinde stringat ligamentum cum corrigia, et inuoluat eam bis.	 Then he ties a ligature with a cord and wraps it around twice.
Et sit strictura temperata, quoniam strictura quando est inaequalis, aut per superfluitatem in strictura, tunc prohibet cursum sanguinis: aut in mollificatione, tunc etiam prohibet cursum sanguinis.	 And let the ligature be moderated, because if the ligature is unequal or excessive in tightening, then it prevents the flow of blood; or in loosening, it also prevents the flow of blood.
Deinde post stricturam oportet, ut fricet phlebotomandus manus suas simul adinuicem, donec inflentur uenae, et declarentur sensui.	 Then after tying, it is necessary that the one being bled rub his hands together until the veins swell and become noticeable to the senses.
Deinde abstergat phlebotomator phlebotomum cum pauco oleo, antiquo proprie.	 Then the phlebotomist cleanses the place of bleeding with a little old oil, specifically.
Deinde ponat digitum suum indicem manus sinistrae super ipsam uenam sub loco cuius phlebotomiam uult, parum: ut non fugiat uena, et cassetur percussio.	 Then he places his index finger of the left hand on that vein under the place where he wants to bleed, a little; so that the vein does not run away and the blow is struck accurately.
Quoniam ex uenis est quam inuenis sicut chordam fugientem apud phlebotomiam: et ex eis est quae est plena uentositate: et quando ponis phlebotomum super eam, contrahitur sub phlebotomo, et decipitur phlebotomator, et non aperit phlebotomus uenam: et si aperit eam, est stricta: propter illud ergo oportet, ut firmetur phlebotomator, et sit sollicitus in his rebus omnibus.	 Since it comes from the vein as you find it, like a fleeing cord during bloodletting; and from these [veins] is what is full of windiness; and when you place a lancet upon it, it contracts under the lancet, and the bloodletter is deceived, and the lancet does not open the vein; and if it opens it, it becomes strict; therefore, for this reason, the bloodletter should be firm, and careful in all these matters.
Deinde deponat phlebotomum.	 Draw out the bloodletter. (Incorrect translation due to incomplete sentence. Correct interpretation would be "Therefore,
Si ergo aperitur uena ex uice una, tunc bonum est.	 If it opens a vein from one side, then it is good.
Et si non, tunc itera illud uice alia sub illo loco parum, aut supra ipsum cum festinatione: si non apostematur locus.	 And if not, then do the same on the other side in that place again or above it with haste; if there is no response, try another location.
Quod si apostematur, aut expauescit infirmus, tunc dimitte eum die, aut duobus diebus: et non stringat ligamentum.	 If there is no response or the person faints weakly, then let him go for a day or two; and do not tighten the bandage.
Fortasse enim attrahet apostema calidum.	 Perhaps it attracts an abscess with heat. (The translation is somewhat conjectural based on the context of the text.)
Neque ingrediatur balneum.	 Do not enter the bath.
Deinde iteret phlebotomiam, si amat.	 Then repeat bloodletting, if necessary.
Quod si apertio est parua, aut currit sanguis subtiliter: et times ut non egrediatur ex sanguine quantitas quam uis: tunc itera phlebotomum in foramine ipso secundum rectitudinem, et adde in operatione parum.	 If the opening is small or the blood flows finely and runs quickly, then fear lest an amount of blood does not come out as desired; then repeat the bloodletting in the same hole according to correctness, and add slightly more in the procedure.
Et fac illud cum festinatione, antequam apostemetur locus, apostematus enim locus est in multis hominibus apud operationem paruam.	 And do this quickly before the location faints, for the fainted location is common among many people during a small procedure.
Si ergo uides ipsum iam apostematum, tunc non iteres super ipsum omnino, non enim excusat apud te aliquid.	 If therefore you see that it has already turned into an abscess, then do not repeat over it at all, for it does not excuse anything in front of you.
Et pone super ipsum aliquid ex faece olei: quoniam alleuiat cursum sanguinis.	 Place something from the face of oil on it; because it soothes the flow of blood.
Et est melior in hoc loco quam oleum ipsum, et quam reliqua olea.	 And this place is better than oil itself and the rest of the olive oil.
Et similiter administra faecem olei in omni phlebotomia tua, qua phlebotomas uenas apud prohibitionem cursus sanguinis: et faciunt illud tyriaca alfarach, et sagzenea, quando ponitur ex una earum super locum.	 And similarly administer oil poultice in every of your bloodlettings, where you bloodlet the veins against prohibition of blood flow: and they do it Tyrian alfarach, and sagzenea, when it is placed on one of them.
Sanguis enim subtiliatur et resoluitur, quando est grossus.	 Blood is made subtle and dissolved when it is thick.
Quod si accidat in loco phlebotomiae apostema magnum, nam multotiens accidit, praecipue ei qui non est phlebotomatus nisi uice illa, aut est apertio uenae parua, tunc propera et pone super locum spongiam infusam in aqua et sale, calefacta parumper: et stringe eam hora una: quoniam soluitur.	 If it happens at the site of bloodletting a large abscess, which often occurs, especially to one who is not a bloodletter except in that case, or is a small opening of the vein, then hasten and place on the spot a sponge soaked in water and salt, warmed slightly: and press it for an hour: because it dissolves.
Et oportet, ut facias illud post exitum sanguinis ex uena ipsa, cum complemento sui, aut ex uena alia.	 It is necessary that you make that [thing] after the exit of blood from the vein itself, when it is full, or from another vein.
Quod si remanet in loco post dies aliquid nigredinis, aut uiriditatis, non nocet illud: et si uis, pone super ipsum aliquid aloe, aut myrrhae solutorum: aut aliquid ex succo menthastri, id est, calamenti aut simile illius.	 If something remains in the place after several days of blackness or greenness, it does not harm it; and if you wish, put on top of it some aloes or myrrh dissolved, or something from the juice of mint, that is to say, camphor or similar.
Et multotiens quidem accidunt apostemata et eminentiae apud phlebotomiam Basilicae.	 And indeed, many times abscesses and protrusions occur near phlebotomy in the Basilica.
Pone ergo manum tuam super ipsam, tunc si inuenis molliciem apud compressionem tuam super ipsam, tunc illa eminentia est mala.	 Therefore put your hand on it [the abscess or protrusion], then if you find softness under your compression on it, then that protrusion is bad.
Caue ergo, ut ponas super eam aliquid ex eo quod diximus.	 Be careful, so that you put something from what I said [camphor or mint juice] on it [the abscess or protrusion].
Nam fortasse fluet ex ea sanguis arteriae.	 For perhaps blood will flow from it [the abscess or protrusion] of the artery.
Sed fac emplastrum ei cum eo in quo est stipticitas, ut induretur locus.	 But make an ointment for it with that [camphor or mint juice], so that the place hardens.
Deinde cura ipsum cum reliqua curatione, donec sanetur.	 Then take care of it [the abscess or protrusion] with the rest of the treatment until it is healed.
Et oportet, ut extrahas omni homini ex sanguine secundum quantitatem uirtutis suae.	 It is necessary that you draw blood from every man according to the quantity of its virtue.
Et quod apparet ex colore uincente super sanguinem.	 And what appears as a clotting color on top of the blood.
Nam sanguis si est niger, tunc dimitte ipsum exire, donec rubeat: et similiter si uides ipsum grossum: tunc dimitte eum, donec subtilietur: et similiter si est acutus, donec auferatur acuitas eius.	 For if the blood is black, then let it come out until it turns red; and similarly if you see it clotted: then let it come out until it becomes thinned; and similarly if it is sharp, let it go out until its sharpness is removed.
Et oportet ei qui est plenus, fortis, et indiget extractione sanguinis uice una, ut amplificetur phlebotomia uenae, et sit phlebotomus latus: et in eo qui est debilis, sit econtrario illius.	 It is necessary for the one who is full, strong, and needs bloodletting once with force, to have a vein enlargement [vena amplificetur] and be a bloodletter on that side; and for the one who is weak, it should be otherwise.
Et oportet, ut extrahat ipsum in uicibus, et ut sit foramen strictum: et melius quod administratur in phlebotomia uenae est, ut sit transuersa sectio, non punctura.	 It is necessary that [he] draws it out in the veins and that there is a narrow opening: and better is what is administered in venesection, that it is a cross-section, not a puncture.
Et iste modus phlebotomiae est saluus a fluxu sanguinis, et ab incisione nerui: et est laudabilior, et saluior quam phlebotomia per latitudinem et longitudinem.	 This mode of venesection is safe from bleeding and from injury to the nerve: and it is more praiseworthy and safer than venesection by width and length.
Et cui consueuit peruenire apud phlebotomiam syncopis, oportet ut cibes ante phlebotomiam modico pane infuso in aqua granati muzi: aut secaniabin, si est calefactus: et extrahas ei ex sanguine in tribus uicibus, aut quatuor.	 To the one who usually faints during venesection, it is necessary that he be given a small piece of bread soaked in water and honey before venesection; or if he is heated, let him be bled with leeches on three or four veins.
Et si est infrigidatae complexionis, tunc accipiat ante phlebotomiam panem infusum in syrupo miua, aut in syrupo de melle aromatizato cum speciebus, aut in syrupo aromatizato odorifero.	 If he is of a cold temperament, then let him take before venesection bread soaked in honey-syrup, or honey-syrup flavored with spices, or aromatic scented syrup.
Quod si accidat syncopis apud phlebotomiam, et est caussa eius exitus sanguinis multi: tunc oportet, ut sumat in potu aquam carnis, et syrupum odoriferum subtilem: et utatur aromaticitate cum algalia, et liniatur pectus eius cum ea: et utatur reliquis quae diximus in diuisione in capitulo syncopis ex euacuatione.	 If fainting occurs during venesection and the cause is excessive blood loss, then it is necessary that he drink meat broth and subtle aromatic syrup; and use aromatics with alum and line his chest with it; and use the rest as mentioned in the division on fainting due to evacuation in the chapter on fainting.
Qui autem uult euentare brachium suum, et soluere sanguinem suum secundo: oportet ei cuius phlebotomia est propter euacuationem multam, et uirtus eius est debilis, ut soluat sanguinem paulatim per quantitatem uirtutis in diebus continuis.	 He who wishes to lose his arm and let go of his blood by the second method: it is necessary for him whose venesection is due to excessive evacuation, and whose strength is weak, that he lets out his blood slowly according to the amount of his strength on consecutive days.
Qui uero uult euentare brachium suum, et soluere sanguinem suum secundo, et est corpus eius forte: tunc faciat illud post septem horas, aut nouem a phlebotomia sua prima.	 But he who wishes to lose his arm and let go of his blood by the second method, and his body is robust: then let him do that seven or nine hours after his first venesection.
Qui autem uult attrahere sanguinem ex corpore suo ad contrarium partis ad quam declinat: oportet ut euentetur ei in die secundo, aut in tertio.	 But he who wishes to draw blood from his body towards the opposite side from which it is flowing: then let him do that on the second or third day.
In cuius uero corpore est sanguis multus iam calefactus, et acuitur, et facit accidere febrem: oportet, ut egrediatur ex eo sanguis in uice una, et extrahatur ex eo quantitas multa: et amplificetur apertio usquequo accidat syncopis: postquam tu fueris conseruans omnes conditiones phlebotomiae: et ut ponas manum tuam super pulsum eius apud cursum sanguinis, ut non accidat mors loco syncopis.	 In whose body there is already much heated blood, which becomes sharp and causes fever: it is necessary that the blood exits from it once, and a large amount is drawn out of it; and the incision should be enlarged until syncope occurs; after you have observed all the conditions of phlebotomy; and to place your hand on his pulse at the flow of blood, so that death does not occur in place of syncope.
Multotiens enim accidit illud, quando ignorat phlebotomator, et cadit negligentia.	 Much happens when the phlebotomist is ignorant and it falls due to negligence.
Et non oportet quando uis soluere brachium, et soluere sanguinem secundo, cum iam clausum sit orificium uenae, et fiat difficilis exitus sanguinis, ut prematur super ipsum cum uehementia, et curuatum extendatur uelociter.	 It is not necessary when you wish to solve the arm and draw blood in the second, if the opening of the vein is already closed, and the exit of blood becomes difficult, that pressure be applied with haste on it, and it should be quickly extended.
Nam illud est malum ualde, imo dimitte ipsum, donec phlebotometur secundo.	 This is very bad indeed, rather let it be, until it can be bled in the second.
Aut remoue cum acuitate phlebotomi illud quod coagulatum est ex sanguine in orificio uenae, et pone super ipsum aliquid salis dissoluti in aqua.	 Either remove with sharpness the coagulated part of blood in the vein's opening, and place something dissolved salt in water upon it.
Et pone super ipsum aliquid ex tyriaca alfaroch, aut sagzenea, et pone ipsum compressione leni, donec egrediatur sanguis.	 And place upon it some from terebinth or aloe, or sage, and put pressure on it gently until the blood exits.
Si uero iam apostemata est uena, tunc dimitte eam, et non tegas eam, donec sedetur apostema.	 If, however, the vein is already cut, then let it be, and do not cover it until the abscess subsides.
Quod si necessitas prouocat ad soluendum sanguinem secundo, et non est excusatio, tunc aut phlebotoma ipsum supra illum locum, aut in brachio alio in uena alia.	 If the necessity compels drawing blood in the second, and there is no excuse, then either bleed at that spot, or in another vein of the arm.
Funis autem brachii phlebotomatur loco Fuscae, et Basilicae, cum non inueniuntur, et sunt occultae, quoniam est composita ex eis.	 The string of the arm is bled at the place of Fuscus and Basilica, when they are not found and hidden because it is composed of them.
Et qualitas phlebotomiae eius est, ut intromittat infirmus manum suam in aqua calida, donec rubeat focile, et appareat uena manifeste.	 And the quality of bleeding him is that the weak hand should be inserted into warm water until it turns red and the vein becomes manifest.
Deinde stringatur super ipsam cum ligamento parum constrictione media.	 Then bind over it with a slightly loose ligature.
Deinde phlebotoma secundum transuersationem paulatim, non latitudinaliter, neque secundum longitudinem: et sit apertio ampla, et sit phlebotomia tua qua eam phlebotomas super iuncturam manus parumper.	 Then perform venesection across, not lengthwise, slowly and not widely; let the opening be large, and your venesection should be on the joint of the hand somewhat.
Quod si prohibetur exitus sanguinis, tunc itera manum in aqua calida, et dimitte sanguinem currere in aqua, donec consequaris necessitatem tuam.	 If the outflow of blood is forbidden, then immerse your hand in hot water and let the blood run into the water until you reach your need.
Si autem fueris in diebus aestatis, tunc excusaris ab iteratione manus in aqua calida.	 But if it is during the summer days, then you are exempted from immersing your hand in hot water.
Et plurimum quidem ponitur cursus sanguinis in aqua calida in tempore hyemis.	 And it is highly recommended that the flow of blood into hot water takes place during wintertime.
Et phlebotomia huius uenae est saluior omnibus uenis, quoniam non est sub ea uena pulsatilis, neque neruus.	 And this vein's venesection is safer for all veins because it is not a pulsating vein and there is no nerve under it.
Phlebotomia uero Saluatellae manus dextrae, est conferens aegritudinibus epatis.	 The venesection of the cephalic vein on the right hand is beneficial for liver diseases.
Et qualitas phlebotomiae eius est, ut stringas mahason manus cum ligamento, aut manu tua, postquam tu intromittis eam in aquam calidam, donec infletur uena, et demonsteretur sensui ualde.	 And the quality of its venesection is that you bind the cephalic vein on the hand with a ligature or by hand after you insert it into hot water, until the vein becomes inflamed and is demonstrated strongly.
Deinde phlebotoma eam transuersando.	 Then perform venesection across (it).
Et si incidis eam totaliter, non nocebit ei illud in aliquo.	 And if you cut it entirely, it will not harm her in any way.
Et conserua, ne ultimes manum tuam cum phlebotomo.	 Keep it, do not go to the end of your hand with the venesection.
Sub ea enim sunt nerui digitorum denudati ex carne.	 For under that are the exposed nerves of the fingers.
Deinde itera manum ad aquam calidam, et dimitte currere sanguinem in ea.	 Then immerse your hand in hot water and let the blood run into it.
Nam si tu non iteras eam in aqua calida, coagulatur sanguis in orificio uenae, et prohibetur a cursu.	 For if you do not immerse it in hot water, the blood clots in the vein opening and it is forbidden from flowing.
Cum ergo extraxeris ex sanguine quantitatem necessitatis, tunc pone super uenam oleum et sal: ut non consolidetur uelociter.	 When you have extracted the amount of blood needed, then place oil and salt on the vein to prevent it from clotting quickly.
Et similiter oportet, ut facias cum omni ramo stricto.	 And similarly, it is necessary that you do with every tight branch.
Iuuamentum uero phlebotomiae eius ex manu sinistra, est: quoniam est conferens ad aegritudines splenis: et similiter fac in phlebotomia eius, sicut fecisti in secunda aequaliter.	 The remedy for bleeding from this [area] is with the left hand. Because it is helpful for sickness of the spleen; and similarly do as you did in the second [case], equally.
Saphenae autem phlebotomiae iuuamentum, est ad aegritudines quae sunt in inferiori parte corporis, sicut aegritudines matricum, et retentionem menstruorum, et infirmitates renum, et ulcera coxarum et crurium antiqua, et similia ex aegritudinibus.	 The remedy for bleeding from the saphenous vein is helpful for sicknesses that are in the lower part of the body, such as illnesses of the womb, retention of menstruation, and weaknesses of kidneys, and ulcers of the hips and legs of old age, and similar illnesses.
Et qualitas phlebotomiae eius est, ut intromittat infirmus pedem suum in aquam calidam: et faciat super ipsum fricationem, donec exuberent uenae: et liga supra iuncturam pedis cum corrigia.	 And the quality of bleeding from this [vein] is that a weak foot is to be introduced into warm water; and make friction on it until veins appear; and tie above the joint of the foot with shoelaces.
Et uenae quidem locus est apud calcaneum, apparens uersus pollicem: et ramificantur ex ea in facie pedis rami multi.	 The vein's location is near the heel, visible towards the thumb; and it branches out from there into many branches on the face of the foot.
Phlebotoma ergo eam in ampliore ramo eius, aut apud calcaneum in aggregatione eius: quoniam est melius et saluius.	 Therefore, bleeding should be done in a larger branch of it, or near the heel in its mass; because it is better and safer.
Quod si phlebotomas eam in facie pedis, tunc caue a neruis qui sunt sub ea super faciem pedis.	 If bleeding is done on the face of the foot, then be careful of the nerves that are under it on the surface of the foot.
Et pone phlebotomiam tuam qua eam phlebotomas ex transuerso, quasi tu uelis incidere eam: et sit phlebotomus Nesil.	 And place your bleeding instrument as if you want to cut it across, like a knife; and the name of the one who bleeds is Nesil.
Si autem prohibetur exitus sanguinis, tunc itera pedem eius in aqua calida: et dimitte sanguinem currere in eam, donec euacuatur.	 If there is a prohibition of the outflow of blood, then immerse his foot in warm water; and let the blood flow into it until it has been released.
Quod si errat uenam phlebotomator in prima uice, tunc iteret cum phlebotomia ad superiora parumper, nam locus est saluus, et non times ex eo maliciam, quando tu caues a neruis, sicut diximus.	 If the vein is missed by the one who bleeds in the first attempt, then let him repeat with bleeding to a slightly higher location, for it is safe, and do not fear harm from it when you are careful of the nerves, as we have said.
Et similiter cum Saphena pedis alterius aequaliter.	 And similarly with the saphenous vein of the other foot equally.
Venae autem Sciaticae locus, sicut diximus, est apud calcaneum ex latere syluestri.	 The location of the Sciatic nerve, as we have said, is at the calcaneum from the forest side.
Et iuuamentum phlebotomiae eius est, ad dolorem anchae, quando est propter sanguinem calidum.	 And its remedy for phlebotomy is, for pain in the ankle, when it is due to hot blood.
Et qualitas phlebotomiae eius est, ut ingrediatur infirmus balneum, et festinet: et stringe crus eius a latere anchae usque supra calcaneum quatuor digitis, cum uitta subtili longa: non enim apparet nisi propter illud.	 And the quality of phlebotomy for it is that the sick should enter the bath and hurry: and tie the leg from the side of the ankle up to the calcaneum with four fingers, with long fine bandage; for it does not appear unless for that reason.
Quando ergo apparet, tunc phlebotoma eam secundum quodcumque ingenium est tibi possibile, aut secundum transuersionem: et est melius, aut ut incidas eam incisione, aut seces eam sectione.	 When it appears then, the vein should be punctured as your ability allows, either in a crossing manner or longitudinally; and it is better, either to cut it with an incision, or to sever it with a section.
Locus enim eius est saluior, et ipsa est in pluribus hominibus occulta ualde.	 For its location is safer, and it is very hidden in many people.
Quod si non inuenis eam, et non apparet sensui omnino: tunc phlebotoma aliquem ramum eius, et est ille qui apparet in dorso pedis, et uersus auricularem: et caue a neruis, et fac currere ex sanguine quantitatem quam uis.	 If you do not find it and it does not appear to the senses at all; then phlebotomy another branch of it, and there is one that appears on the back of the foot, turned towards the ear; and beware of nerves, and let the amount of blood run as much as you wish.
Deinde solue stricturam, et pone super locum phlebotomiae corium, et stringe locum.	 Then dissolve the constriction, and place the skin over the location for phlebotomy, and tie the location.
Uelociter enim sanatur.	 It is quickly cured.
¶ De Ventosatione, et qualitate usus eius.	 On Windbagging, and the quality of its use.
Caput XCVIII.	 Head LXXXVIII.
Uentosae fiunt ex cornibus, et ex aere, et ex uitro.	 Wounds are made from horns, and from copper, and from glass.
Et Ventosatio quidem fit secundum duos modos.	 And ventilation is performed in two ways.
Cum scarificatione, et extractione sanguinis: et alter est uentosatio sine scarificatione.	 With incision (scarification) and bloodletting; another way of ventilation is without incision.
Et haec Ventosatio quae est sine scarificatione, est secundum duos modos.	 And this ventilation that is without incision is also performed in two ways.
Aut enim est cum igne.	 Or else it is done with fire.
Aut est absque igne.	 Or else it is done without fire.
Et uentosis quae administrantur cum scarificatione et extractione sanguinis sunt quatuordecim loca corporis.	 And the places for ventilation that are administered with incision and bloodletting number fourteen on the body.
Quorum unus est, Ventosatio Alnocrati, et est postremum capitis: et Alkehel, et est medium colli: et uentosae Alhagdahim, et sunt duae laminae colli a duabus partibus simul: et uentosae menti, et est sub mandibula in inferiori oris: et uentosae duarum spatularum: et uentosae Alachosos super finem caudae: et uentosae duorum focilium, et sunt medium duorum brachiorum: et uentosae duorum crurium: et uentosae duarum cauillarum.	 One of these places for ventilation is called Ventosatio Alnocrati, and it is the last on the head; and Alkehel, and it is in the middle of the neck; and ventosae Alhagdahim, which are two layers on the neck from both sides simultaneously; and ventosae menti, which is below the mandible in the lower jaw; and ventosae duarum spatularum; and ventosae Alachosos over the end of the tail; and ventosae duorum focilium, and they are in the middle of two arms; and ventosae duorum crurium; and ventosae duarum cauillarum.
Et Ventosatio quidem non extrahit sanguinem tibi ex uenis minutis sparsis in carne, et propter illud non cadit uirtus ex eis, sicut est casus eius ex phlebotomia.	 And ventilation does not extract blood from small veins scattered in the flesh, and therefore its effectiveness is not as with phlebotomy (bloodletting).
Neque oportet, ut administretur uentosatio siue cum igne, aut absque igne in aliqua aegritudinum quae fiunt ex repletione, donec euacuetur totum corpus.	 It is not necessary to administer ventilation by fire or without fire for any illness that occurs from congestion, until the entire body has been evacuated.
Quod si necessitas prouocat ad Ventosationem ex aegritudine, aut propter consuetudinem, administramus eam in omni hora in principio mensis, in fine eius, et in medio ipsius, et in quocumque tempore fuerit.	 If necessity requires ventilation due to illness or custom, we administer it at any hour, at the beginning of the month, at its end, and in the middle, and whenever it is needed.
Quod est, quia ex hominibus est qui quando multiplicatur in eo sanguis, donec indiget extractione eius per uentosationem, inuenit in capite suo grauedinem, et sodahan.	 Because there are people who, when their blood multiplies, until it needs to be extracted through ventilation, find a headache and pain in their head.
Et ex eis est qui inuenit repletionem et rubedinem in facie sua, capite suo, et collo suo.	And from these [conditions] is he who finds swelling and redness on his face, on his head, and on his neck.
Et ex eis est qui inuenit pruritum in facie sua, et fronte sua, et tenebrositatem, et hebetudinem in oculis suis.	 And from these [conditions] is he who finds itching on his face, forehead, and darkness, and dullness in his eyes.
Et ex eis est qui scalpit locum uentosationis suae.	 And from these [conditions] is he who scratches the place of his wind-inflammation.
Et ex eis est cuius risus multiplicatur.	 And from these [conditions] is he whose laughter increases.
Et ex eis est qui inuenit gustum sanguinis in ore suo: aut apostematur lingua, et expuit sanguinem.	 And from these [conditions] is he who finds the taste of blood in his mouth: or the tongue is thrust out and cleansed the blood.
Et ex eis est cuius somnus multiplicatur.	 And from these [conditions] is he whose sleep increases.
Et ex eis est qui uidet in somno suo sanguinem et rubedinem, et interfectos, et plagas, et quae sunt similia illis.	 And from these [conditions] is he who sees in his dream blood and redness, and the dead, and wounds, and similar things.
Quando ergo uidemus aliquid ex illis, et proprie si est in tertia media mensis: praecipimus tunc uentosationem fieri, postquam praeterierunt de die duae horae, aut tres.	 When we see something from these [conditions], and properly if it is in the third month: then we command wind-inflammation to be made, after two or three hours have passed.
Iuuamentum autem Ventosationis nuchae, est: quoniam ipsa confert ad grauitatem in capite, et quod effunditur ad oculos.	 But the remedy for wind-inflammation of the neck is: because it contributes to heaviness in the head, and what is exuded goes to the eyes.
At uero oportet, ut sit illud post euacuationem totius corporis.	 However, it must be that this [treatment] is after the evacuation of the entire body.
Et haec quidem Ventosa est loco phlebotomiae Cephalicae.	 And indeed wind-inflammation is in the place of cephalic phlebotomy.
Et non licet, ut utatur ea qui est frigidae complexionis, aut in quo est catarrus.	 But it is not allowed to use this [treatment] for one who is of cold constitution, or in whom there is catarrh.
Nam infert ei nocumentum magnum.	 For it causes great harm to him.
Et propter illud non oportet, ut utantur ea senes, et in cuius capite sunt aegritudines frigidae.	 And for that reason, it is not proper to use this [treatment] by the elderly and in one whose head has cold diseases.
Qui autem super eam fit assiduus, generatur super eum obliuio.	 But he who becomes habitual over it generates forgetfulness upon him.
Et propter illud oportet, ut praecipias Ventosatori, ut deponat manum suam cum uentosa parumper ad inferiora, timendo ex generatione obliuionis.	 And for that reason, you should command the wind-inflator to lay down his hand with the wind-inflation briefly towards the lower parts, fearing from the generation of forgetfulness.
Ventosatio aut Alkehel, est loco phlebotomiae Fuscae, et phlebotomiae Basilicae, et propter illud confert asmati, et constrictioni anhelitus, et fissurae instrumenti anhelitus, et tussi, et repletioni.	 Ventosatio or Alkehel, is a place for phlebotomy of Fuscae, and phlebotomy of Basilicae, and it corresponds to suffocation, constriction of breath, fissure of instruments breath, cough, and repletion.
Et oportet, ut impellatur Ventosa Alkehel parumper, quoniam si ponitur inferius, generat debilitatem in corde, et stomacho.	 And it is necessary that the Alkehel Ventosatio is pushed a little, because if it is placed below, it generates weakness in the heart and the stomach.
Ventosatio uero alhagdahim, confert doloribus accidentibus in capite, et obtalmiae, et hemigraneae, et perforationi, et dolori in radicibus dentium: et est loco phlebotomiae Basilicae.	 Ventosatio alhagdahim corresponds to pain in the head, migraine, ophthalmia, perforation, and dental root pain; it is a place for phlebotomy of Basilicae.
Et oportet, ut praecipias Ventosatori, ne premat manum suam cum scarificatione: ut non incidat arteriam, et accidat fluxus sanguinis.	 And it is necessary that you advise the Ventosator not to press his hand during scarification; so as not to cut an artery and cause blood flow.
Ventosatio autem sub mento, confert alcolae in ore, et corruptioni gingiuae, et similibus eis ex aegritudinibus quae sunt in ore: et stat loco phlebotomiae alieherich, quae sunt in duobus labiis.	 Ventosation below the chin causes alcohol in the mouth, corruption of gums, and similar illnesses in the mouth; it is a place for phlebotomy at another location which are on the two lips.
Ventosatio autem spatularum, confert ad alchafacham, quae fit ex replexione, et caliditate.	 Ventosation of spatulas causes alchafacham, which is caused by repletion and heat.
Ventosatio uero interiorum partium duorum focilium, confert iuuamentum phlebotomiae uenarum trium, Basilicae, et Fuscae, et Cephalicae: quoniam ipsa attrahit sanguinem ex omnibus illis uenis minutis, quae sunt in carne: et attrahunt illae uenae minutae ex uenis aliis grossioribus eis, donec peruenit attractio ad uenas tres.	 But ventosation of the internal parts of two oval-shaped areas confers benefit to phlebotomy of three veins: Basilicae, Fuscae, and Cephalicae; because it draws blood from all the small veins that are in the flesh; and these small veins draw blood from larger veins until the attraction reaches the three veins.
Et oportet, ut praecipias Ventosatori, ne multum procedat in scarificatione: quoniam locus est denudatus carne, et sub eo sunt nerui et arteriae.	 And it is necessary that you advise the Ventosator not to go too deep in scarification; because the place is bare of flesh, and beneath it are nerves and arteries.
Ventosa autem quae uentosatur super alchausos, confert hemorroidibus Ani, et ulceribus inferioribus.	 But ventosation that ventosates on the testicles confers hemorrhoids of the anus and lower ulcers.
Et oportet, ut praecipias Ventosatori, ut sit uentosa magna, et ut sit ex aere: quoniam locus indiget suctione forti, et fortasse franguntur Ventosae subtiles: et scarificetur scarificatione magna.	 It is necessary that you instruct the Venti Sorber, it should be a large windbag and made of air, since the place requires strong suction and perhaps subtle winds break; it should be cut with deep incisions.
Ventosae autem crurium minuunt diminutione manifesta: quoniam attrahunt sanguinem ex toto corpore, et conferunt doloribus antiquis in renibus, et matricibus, et uesica: prouocant menstrua, et conferunt bothor, et ademenul: et stant loco phlebotomiae duarum saphenarum, et alhorcobeni.	 The winds of the legs diminish by obvious reduction, since they draw blood from the whole body and bring old pains to kidneys, womb, and bladder; they provoke menstruation, cause bile and phlegm; and they are located in place of venesection of two saphenous veins and alhorcobeni.
Verumtamen debilitant corpus multum, et faciunt accidere syncopim in pluribus hominibus.	 However, they weaken the body greatly, and cause fainting in many men.
Et Ventosarum alhorcobeni iuuamentum est propinquum iuuamento Ventosarum duorum crurium.	 And the remedy of Alhorcoben for winds is close to the remedy for winds of two legs.
Qualitas positionis Ventosarum est, ut ponas uentosam in primis uacuam, et sugas suctione temperata: et non prolonges positionem uentosarum, sed pone eas uelociter, et remoue eas uelociter, ut ueniant humores ad locum aduentu aequali: et non cesses iterare illud et continuare, donec uideas locum iam rubere et inflari, et appareat rubedo sanguinis: tunc ergo scarifica, et itera suctione paulatim.	 The quality of the positioning for winds is that you place the windbag first in an empty place, and suck with moderate suction; do not prolong the positioning of winds, but place them quickly, and remove them quickly, so that humors come to the place with equal arrival; and do not cease to repeat this and continue until you see the place redden and swell, and the redness appears to be blood; then scarify, and repeat suction gradually.
Deinde considera in dispositione corporum.	 Then consider in positioning of bodies.
Nam qui ex hominibus est tenerae carnis, rarorum pororum, oportet ut scarifices ipsum semel, non plus: ut non ulceretur locus.	 For if a man is of tender flesh and few pores, it is necessary that you scarify him once, not more; so that the place does not ulcerate.
Et praecipe Ventosatori, ut amplificet scarificationem, et profundet parum: et temperet suctionem in facilitate, et uelocitate, et motu suaui.	 And instruct the Venti Sorber, to expand the incision and make it shallow; and moderate the suction in ease, speed, and gentle movement.
Quod si in sanguine est grossitudo, tunc oportet, ut scarifices ipsum bis.	 If there is thickening in the blood, then it is necessary that you scarify him twice.
In uice quidem prima aperitur uia subtiliationi sanguinis, et aquositati eius: et in secunda quidem perscrutationi exquisitae extractionis sanguinis grossi.	 In the first case, an opening is made for refining the blood and its watering; and in the second case, for a detailed examination of the extraction of thick blood.
Si uero sanguis est faeculentus ualde, tunc fiat scarificatio uice tertia: ut consequatur ultimum.	If the blood is extremely impure, then make an incision in its place, to follow up on the last one.
Et ad ultimum, quando uolumus extrahere sanguinem paulatim, uel parumper, sufficit nobis scarificatio una.	 And when we wish to draw blood gradually or slightly, a single incision is sufficient for us.
Quod si uolumus extractionem sanguinis multi, scarificamus scarificatione plurima.	 If we wish to draw much blood, we make many incisions.
Et si nos mensuramus, quod sanguis est grossus: tunc oportet, ut scarificetur scarificatione profunda: et terminus aequalis in scarificatione, est profunditas cutis.	 And if we measure that the blood is thick, then it is necessary to make a deep incision, and the length of the incision equal in depth is the thickness of the skin.
¶ Quid sit illud quod oportet administrari ex oleis apud positionem Ventosarum, et quid caueat uentosandus.	 What is that which should be administered from oils for the position of Ventosaries, and what should be avoided in venting them.
IN illo quidem cuius cutis est grossa, dura, fusca, et pori eius sunt stricti, oportet ut ungantur loca Ventosare cum oleis apertiuis, lenitiuis, resolutiuis: si est in tempore aestatis, sicut est oleum alkeiri, aut oleum uiolatum, aut oleum de amigdalis dulcibus, aut oleum de semine cucurbitae.	 In the case where the skin is thick, hard, dark, and the pores are narrow, it is necessary to anoint the Ventosaries with open, softening, resolving oils: if it is in summer, for example, aloe oil, or olive oil, or oil of sweet almonds, or seed oil of pumpkin.
Et si est in tempore hyemis, tunc oleum narcissinum, aut oleum de lilio, aut oleum camomellinum, aut sarbatinum: et eis similia.	 And if it is in winter, then narcissus oil, or lily oil, or chamomile oil, or savory oil, and similar ones should be used.
Si uero superfluitas est grossa, frigida: tunc oleum sit amaracinum, aut oleum de balsamita aut oleum alben, aut oleum anetinum: et eis similia.	 If there is excessive thick and cold secretion, then bitter almond oil, balm oil, white oil or dittany oil should be used, and similar ones.
Si uero uentosandus est amplorum pororum, tenerae carnis: tunc oportet, ut prohibeatur ab oleo, et oportet ut isti abluant loca Ventosarum earum post uentosationem cum aqua rosata, aut cum aqua frigida, aut cum aqua solatri, aut cum aqua cucurbitae, aut cum aqua portulacae: et similibus eis.	 If the venting is from large pores and soft flesh, then oil should be prohibited, and the areas of Ventosaries should be washed with rose water, cold water, salt water, pumpkin water, or purslane water, and similar ones after venting.
Ille autem cuius sanguis est multae humiditatis, abluat uentosas cum aceto, aut cum aqua myrti, et sumach: et similibus eis.	 The one whose blood is much moisture, should wash the ventosaries with vinegar or with water of myrtle and sumac, and similar ones.
Cuius autem superfluitates sunt grossae, abluat uentosas suas cum uino antiquo, aut cum aqua samsuci, aut decoctione aneti, aut camomillae: et eis similibus.	 When the superfluities are gross, wash them with windy wine, or with rose water, or with anise decoction, or with chamomile: and similar things.
Et oportet, ut caueatur uentosatio in balneo, aut in uestigio balnei, imo oportet, ut administretur post exitum ex balneo per horam, aut per horas duas.	 It is necessary to avoid windiness in the bath or near the bath, rather it should be administered after leaving the bath for an hour, or for two hours.
Et non oportet, ut dormiat aliquis post uentosationem.	 And it is not necessary that someone sleeps after windiness.
¶ Quid est quo oportet ut regatur Ventosandus, aut Phlebotomatus ante uentosationem.	 What is the thing that should be regulated for a Wind-sender or a Blood-letter before windiness.
ET post eam oportet, ut consideres in primis: tunc si Ventosatus, aut Phlebotomatus sit cholericus, et uincunt super sanguinem eius acuitas et inflammatio: tunc oportet, ut accipiat infrigidantia, sicut granatum muzum: et etiam endiuiam cum aceto et lactuca, et secaniabin, et iuleb: et eis similia.	 And after that it is necessary to consider first: if the Wind-sender or the Blood-letter is choleric and bitterness and inflammation overcome his blood, then it is necessary for him to receive cooling things such as musk-grape, and also fig with vinegar and lettuce, and cucumber, and yoghurt: and similar things.
Et pone cibaria eius pullos, et carnes ouium sekebiget, et cibos conditos cum agresta: et eis similia.	 And place his food with young birds, and lean mutton meat, and seasoned foods with vinegar: and similar things.
Et cuius complexio est frigida, oportet ut sumat in potu syrupum de melle, aut de almiua, aut alsecaniabin de seminibus factum: et sumat uinum odoriferum medium, quod est inter uetus et nouum: et praecipiatur, ut utatur paucitate cibi.	 And when his complexion is cold, let him drink syrup made from honey or almonds, or a sauce made from cucumber seeds: and he should drink moderately flavored wine which is between old and new wine: and it is recommended that he uses little food.
Et pone cibum eius pullos, et canebir: et passeres, id est, paruas aues: et pullos columborum issiadebet.	 And place his food with young birds, quails and small birds: and also pigeons for him to eat.
Et oportet, ut potus die uentosationis et phlebotomiae plus sit quam cibus: et oportet, ut detur in potu in quibusdam hominibus in horis tyriaca alfaroch, aut medicamen de musco, id est, muscata, aut alesselithe ante uentosationem: et ante phlebotomiam, aut post: ut confortentur membra principalia, et subtilietur sanguis.	 And it is necessary that the drink on the day of windiness and blood-letting be more than food: and it should be given in drink to some people for hours of tarragon or alfaroch, or medicine from musk, that is muscat, or ale-selle before windiness and after: so as to strengthen the main limbs, and make the blood thin.
Et non oportet, ut sumant eam in potu calefacto.	 And it is not appropriate for them to take [it] in a hot drink.
¶ De Ventosis sine scarificatione.	 About Ventoses without incision.
Uentosae autem quae sunt sine scarificatione, sunt Ventosae quae ponuntur super epar, et splenem, et podagram, et super uentrem, umbilicum, et loca renum, et pixidem anchae: quoniam ista membra non sufferunt scarificationem super se.	 Ventoses which are without incision, are those placed on the liver, spleen, foot, and belly, navel, kidneys, and ankle: because these members cannot bear incision upon them.
Et non quaeritur per eas, nisi aut attactio ex membro sanguinis ad membrum: sicut ponimus Ventosam super mammillas in aegritudine fluxus sanguinis narium.	 And it is not sought through them, except attraction of blood from one member to another: such as placing the Ventose on the breasts in the sickness of nosebleed.
Et utimur eis, ut soluamus a membro uentositatem frigidam inuiscatam in membro: sicut ponimus uentosam super uentrem, et umbilicum.	 And we use them to dissipate the cold humour of windiness unbearable in a member: such as placing the Ventose on the belly and navel.
Ipsa enim rarificat membrum, et calefacit ipsum, et remouet dolorem propterea, quia resoluit illam uentositatem.	 For it makes the member rarefied, and warms it up, and removes pain therefore, because it dissipates that windiness.
Etiam ponitur super renes, quando accidit in eis opilatio, aut lapis.	 Also it is placed on the kidneys when there occurs an obstruction or a stone.
Uirtute enim attractionis suae fortasse aperit opilationem, aut eradicat lapidem ex loco suo.	 By its virtue of attraction perhaps it opens up obstruction, or removes the stone from its place.
Et similiter facit quando ponitur super epar, et splenem apud uentositatem terendam in eis utrisque.	 And likewise it does when placed on the liver and spleen for treading windiness in both of them.
Et istae Ventosae administrantur uacuae cum sectione tantum.	 These Ventoses are applied empty, with incision only.
Et quandoque administrantur cum igne.	 And sometimes they are administered with fire.
Et quandoque administrantur plenae aqua tepida in aegritudinibus pleuresis: et illud est, ut impleatur Ventosa, et sit magna, aqua calida sola, aut aqua in qua decoctae sint herbae quae conueniunt.	 And sometimes they are administered full of warm water in the sicknesses of pleurisy: and that is so that the Ventose is filled, and large, with only warm water, or water in which boiled herbs that agree have been steeped.
¶ Forma Ventosae administratae cum igne.	 About the form of a Ventose administered with fire.
Sit amplitudo orificii eius duorum digitorum apertorum, secundum quod formauimus: et quantitas eius in profundo sit medietas palmi: et sit in latere eius in loco qui est circiter medium eius, foramen paruum, secundum quantitatem quod ingrediatur ipsum acus: fiat ex aere simul, aut citrino, grossorum marginum, lenium, aequalium, tersorum: ut non laedat membrum apud positionem suam super ipsum: et sit in medio eius uirga transuersa ex aere, aut ferro, ubi ponitur candela cum igne.	 Its length should be about the size of a hand, and its width two fingers open, as we have formed it: and its depth should be half a palm: and on its side there should be a small hole, according to the quantity that is entered by the needle: made of brass or citrine, thick edges, smooth, equal, rubbed: so that it does not hurt the member upon which it is placed: and in the middle of it there should be a transverse rod of brass or iron, where the candle with fire is placed.
Et iam fit haec uentosa magna, maior ea quam narrauimus, et parum minor illa, secundum aegritudines et aetatem eius qui utitur.	 And now it becomes this swollen [thing], larger than we have mentioned earlier, and yet somewhat smaller than it was, according to the sickness and age of the one who is using it.
Ventosae enim puerorum, et extenuatorum sunt aliae, quam uentosae uirorum, et grossorum corporum.	 For boys' swellings, and those of thin bodies, are different from the swellings of men, and those with large bodies.
Qualitas autem ponendi hanc uentosam cum igne super membrum, est, ut accendas licinium cum igne ex lino decenter, aut candelam paruam ex caera: et pone eam super medium uirgae transuersae quae est in medio uentosae: ut sit accensus ignis circiter inferiorem partem uentosae, ut non comburatur corpus infirmi.	 The quality of placing this swelling with fire on a limb is that you should kindle a linen cloth with fire properly, or a small candle from wax; and place it over the middle rung which is in the middle of the swelling; so that the fire may be ignited around the lower part of the swelling, but not burn the body of the sick person.
Deinde ponatur super membrum: et digitus sit super foramen quod dixi, donec quando tenemus uentosam: dum indigemus, auferamus digitum, et egredietur uapor super illud foramen, et soluetur uentosa statim.	 Then it is to be placed on the limb; and a finger is over the opening I mentioned, until we hold the swelling; when we need to, we remove the finger, and the vapor comes out through that opening, and the swelling is immediately resolved.
Deinde igni licinium secundum modum suum, et itera eam, si indiges illa.	 Then, kindle the linen cloth according to its manner, and repeat it if needed.
In Ventosa autem quae administratur in aegritudine pleuresis cum aqua, non est uirga transuersa, neque foramen: et non administratur, nisi quia impletur aqua, et ponitur super membrum tantum.	 In the swelling which is applied to the sickness of pleurisy with water, there is no rung across, nor an opening; and it is not administered unless because it is filled with water, and it is placed on the limb only.
Et haec est forma eius.	 And this is its form.
Et haec Ventosa quanto plus est magna, ut capiat aquam multam, est melior.	 And this swelling, when it is larger, in order to hold more water, is better.
¶ De suspensione Sanguisugarum.	 Chapter on the suspension of Sanguisugars.
Caput XCIX.	 Chapter 99.
Sanguisugae non administrantur in pluribus, nisi in quibus membris non est possibilis positio uentosarum, propter paruitatem eorum, sicut labium, et gingiua, et eis similia.	 Chapters XCIX. Sanguisugars are not administered in many places except in those parts of the body where it is impossible to position swellings due to their small size, such as lips, gums, and similar ones.
Aut in membro denudato a carne, sicut digitus, et nasus, et eis similia.	 Or on denuded parts of the body, such as fingers, nose, and similar ones.
Et qualitas utendi eis est: ut ueneris ex Sanguisugis quae sunt in aquis dulcibus, mundis a putredinibus.	 The quality for their use is: as when coming from Leeches that are in sweet waters, cleaned of rottenness.
Deinde dimittantur die et nocte in aqua dulci, donec famelicae sint, et non remaneat in uentre earum aliquid.	 Then they (the leeches) should be let loose day and night in sweet water, until they are hungry, and nothing remains in their stomach.
Deinde euacuetur corpus in primis cum phlebotomia, et cum uentosis.	 Then the body should be evacuated first with venesection (bloodletting), and with purges (emetics).
Deinde absterge membrum infirmi, donec rubeat.	 Then cleanse the sick part until it turns red.
Postea ponantur super ipsum.	 Then they (the leeches) are placed upon it (the cleaned sick part).
Cum ergo implentur, et cadunt, et est possibilis suctio loci cum uentosa, tunc est magis ultimum in iuuamento: et si non, tunc ablue locum cum aceto.	 When they are full and fall, and it is possible to suck the site with a purge, then it is more beneficial for healing; if not, then cleanse the place with vinegar.
Deinde cum aqua multa, et fricetur, et exprimatur.	 Then with much water, rub and press.
Quod si prolongatur cursus sanguinis post casum Sanguisugarum, et est illud resudando: tunc infunde pannum lini in aqua frigida, et pone ipsum desuper, donec abscindatur resudatio.	 If the course of blood persists after the leeches have fallen off, and it is sweating, then immerse a linen cloth in cold water and place it upon it until the sweating stops.
Quod si multiplicatur sanguis, tunc pulueriza super ipsum zegi tritum, aut gallas, et similia eis ex stipticis: donec abscindatur sanguis.	 If the blood increases, then sprinkle powdered zaffran (zegi) or gall nuts and similar substances from the poppy on it until the bleeding stops.
Aut ponantur super locum medietates fabarum excorticatarum: et dimittantur, donec adhaereant fabae in loco, nam sanguis abscinditur.	 Or lay half-peeled beans on the place, and let them stay until the beans stick to the spot, for the blood will stop flowing.
Et oportet si necessaria est iteratio Sanguisugarum, quando est possibile, mutare eas.	 And it is necessary to repeat the use of leeches when possible, if they are needed.
Si autem prohibentur Sanguisugae a suspensione, tunc abstergatur locus cum sanguine recenti.	 If leeches are forbidden from being suspended, then cleanse the place with fresh blood.
Aut fige acum in locis, donec egrediatur aliquid ex sanguine.	 Or make an incision in the places until something comes out of the blood.
