Deinde ponantur, nam ipsae quando sentiunt aliquid ex sanguine, adhaerent statim.	 Then place them (the leeches), for they will stick immediately when they sense something from the blood.
Quando ergo uis ut cadant, pulueriza super eas aliquid ex aloe trito, aut salem, aut cinerem: et cadent statim.	 When you wish for them to fall, sprinkle something from crushed aloes, salt or ashes upon them; they will fall immediately.
¶ Partis Secundae Finis.	 The End of the Second Part.
¶ Liber Chirurgici Albucasis Pars III.	 Book of Surgery by Albucasis, Third Part.
¶ Sermo uniuersalis de restauratione, et dislocatione, et curatione torsionis, et similibus.	 Universal Discourse on Restoration, Dislocation, and Treatment of Torsions and Similar Conditions.
Caput I.	 Chapter One.
Hoc Capitulum etiam multotiens est necessarium in arte Medicinae, et est restauratio fracturae, et dislocationis accidentium in ossibus.	 This Chapter is also often necessary in the art of Medicine; it is the restoration of a fracture and dislocation of bones.
Scitote o Filii, quia iactant se de hoc Capitulo stolidi medicorum et uulgi, et qui non inspexerunt unquam antiquorum librum, neque legerunt ex eo literam.	 Know ye, O Sons, that foolish doctors and the common people boast about this Chapter, and those who have never examined an ancient book or read a letter from it.
Et propter hanc caussam fit, quod iste modus ex scientiis in terra nostra est priuatus.	 And therefore, because this method is lacking among the learned in our land.
Et ego non obuiaui in eo unquam bono omnino, et non adeptus sum ex eo illud, quod sum adeptus nisi propter longitudinem lectionis librorum antiquorum, et studium super intellectum eorum, donec extraxi scientiam illius ex eis.	 And I have never encountered it in a good way, and I have not attained that knowledge from it except for the length of reading ancient books and my diligence in understanding them until I extracted that knowledge from them.
Deinde adhaesi experimento et studio longitudine uitae meae.	 Then I have applied the experiment and diligent study throughout my life.
Et iam descripsi uobis ex illo in hoc Capitulo totum quod continet scientia mea: et super quod praeteriit experimentum meum, postquam abbreuiaui illud uobis, et liberaui illud ex occupatione elongationis, et abbreuiaui illud fine abbreuiationis, et ostendi illud fine declinationis: et formaui in eo formas multas ex formis instrumentorum quae administrantur in eo, cum sit ex additione declinationis, sicut feci in duobus Capitulis praecedentibus.	 Now I have described to you everything that my knowledge contains on this Chapter; and beyond what my experiment has failed, after I have abbreviated it for you, and released it from the prolongation of the explanation, and abbreviated it at the end of the abbreviation, and shown its conclusion; and I have formed many forms of instruments that are applied in it, since it is an addition of a decline, as I did in the two preceding Chapters.
¶ Summae, et collectiones ex esse fracturae ossium, ex eis quarum praemissio necessaria est, antequam incipiamus rememorationem membrorum fractorum, et diuersorum, si uniuscuiusque.	 Summary and collections on the existence of bone fractures, which is necessary before we begin the reminder of broken limbs and various ones, if of any one.
Caput II.	 Chapter Two.
Oportet, ut dicamus in prologo huius Capituli, summas sermonis, et capitula, ad quarum intellectum cogitur in primis artifex ad stationem super earum ueritatem: scilicet ut uos, et qui sunt prompti, sciant, uel addiscant hanc artem nobilem, et alii a uobis.	 It is necessary that we say in the prologue of this Chapter the sums and Chapters, to whose understanding the craftsman must be directed first to his station regarding their truth; namely, so that you and those who are ready know or learn this noble art, and others from you.
Dico, ergo, quod quando accidit alicui fractura, aut dislocatio, aut torsio, aut casus: tunc oportet, ut properes in primis ad phlebotomandum eum, et soluendum ipsum, aut utraque simul: si non prohibeat aliquid, sicut debilitas uirtutis: aut est ille cui accidit aliquid ex illis puer, aut senex decrepitus: aut est tempus uehementis caloris, aut uehementis frigoris ualde.	 I say, therefore, that when anyone happens to have a fracture, or dislocation, or twisting, or fall: then it is necessary, firstly, to rush to let blood from him, and to solve it, or both at the same time: unless something forbids it, such as weakness of strength; or it happens to someone who is a child, or an old and decrepit person; or it is a time of intense heat, or intense cold.
Deinde sit contentus in cibo suo, oleribus frigidis, et carnibus auium, et haedorum: et prohibe uinum, et carnes grossas, et repleri ex cibis et omni cibo qui replet uenas sanguine.	 Let him be content with his own food, cold vegetables, beans and hedgehogs; and let him abstain from wine, large meat portions, and filling himself up with any food or all food that fills the veins with blood.
Donec quando securus sis ex apostemate calido, et non times effusionem materiei ad membrum: tunc redeat infirmus ad regimen suum primum cum quo cucurrit consuetudo eius.	 Until he is secure from a warm abscess, and does not fear the outflow of matter to a limb; then let the sick person return first to his own regime, with which his custom usually runs.
Cum ergo incipit os fractum restaurari, tunc oportet, ut cibetur infirmus cibis nutrientibus nutrimento multo, grosso, graui, in quibus sit uiscositas: sicut cibaria facta ex tritico cocto cum aqua, et rizum, et capita, et pedes, et uentres uaccarum, et oua, et pisces recentes: et uinum grossum, et similia illis.	 When the broken bone begins to heal, then it is necessary for the sick person to eat nourishing foods in abundance, thick, heavy, with viscosity; such as food made from boiled wheat and water, rice, heads of animals, hooves, entrails of cattle, eggs, fresh fish, thick wine, and similar things.
Cum hoc enim regimine fit coagulatio fracturae uelocius, et melius.	 With this regime, the healing of the fracture is made more quickly and better.
Et scias, quod ossa fracta, quando sunt in uiris qui sunt in prima senectute, et decrepitis, non est possibile, ut continuentur et consolidentur secundum naturam suam semper, propter exiccationem membrorum eorum: et consolidantur et continuantur quae ex eis sunt in fine lenitatis, sicut ossa puerornm paruorum.	 And know that broken bones, when they are in men who are in early old age and decrepit, it is not possible for them to be held together and consolidated according to their nature always, due to the drying of their members; and they consolidate and hold together those which are from them at the end of softness, like the bones of small boys.
Verumtamen natura annectit super os fractum ex omni parte aliquid simile glutino, in quo est grossitudo, quo adhaeret et stringit ipsum, donec conglutinantur adinuicem, et ligantur adinuicem, donec uenit in fine fortitudinis et firmitudinis, sicut fuit in primis, donec non prohibet ipsum aliquid ab operationibus suis: et propter hanc caussam est necesse, ut ponas nutrimentum infirmi cibaria, in quibus sunt grauitas, et uiscositas, et grossitudo, sicut diximus.	 Nevertheless, nature connects something similar to glue around the broken bone from every part, in which there is thickness, so that it adheres and tightens it until they are consolidated on both sides, and bind together until it comes to the end of strength and firmness, as it was at first, until something forbids it by its operations; and because of this reason it is necessary to put the nourishment of the sick person in foods which have thickness, viscosity, and heaviness, as we said.
Et scias, quod fracturae species sunt diuersae, secundum diuersitatem membrorum: quoniam fractura cruris, est diuersa a fractura ossis capitis: et fractura ossis pectoris, est diuersa a fractura ossis dorsi: et similiter reliqua membra omnia diuersa existunt adinuicem: et ego ueni cum rememoratione omnis speciei fracturae expositae in Capitulo suo distinctae ab alia.	And know that the types of fractures are diverse, according to the differences of the limbs; for the fracture of the leg is different from the fracture of the head bone; and the fracture of the chest bone is different from the fracture of the back bone; and similarly all other members are diverse one from another; and I come with the reminder of all types of fractures explained in their respective chapters distinctly from each other.
Et diuersificantur species fracturae ossis etiam in seipsa.	 The species of bone fractures are also diverse within themselves.
Quoniam fit fractura eius arcuata, praeter quod accidant in ea astellae.	 As for the bow-shaped fracture, there occur stars (spicules) in it.
Et quandoque fit fractura eius secundum longitudinem ossis: et sunt fracturae eius satagiae, id est, astellae, et additiones procedentes, sicut sunt in calamo, cum aptatur cultello ad scribendum.	 Sometimes a fracture occurs along the length of the bone; and such fractures are called 'stars', that is spicules, or additions proceeding from them, as they are in a reed when it is cut with a knife for writing.
Et non procedentes: et est fractura cum uulnere et disruptione in capite: et est fractura fissura parua.	 Neither proceeding; and there is a fracture with wound and rupture in the head; and there is a small cleft fracture.
Et omni speciei est ingenium, uel instrumentum proprium in restauratione eius, secundum quod ueniet rememoratio eius, distincta in locis suis.	 And every kind has its skill or specific tool for restoration, according to which its memory will come, distinguished in their respective places.
Et ex eo quo cognoscitur fractura ossis, est tortuositas eius, et ipsius eminentia: et apparitio eius sensui, et sonitus eius quando comprimis ipsum manu tua.	 And from the fact that a bone fracture is known, its curvature and its prominence appear to the senses; and its appearance sounds when you compress it with your hand.
Quando ergo non est in loco tortuositas apparens, neque sonitus apud tactum tuum cum tangis os cum agitatione, neque inuenit infirmus magnum dolorem: tunc non est illic fractura, imo possibile est, ut sit tortuositas, aut fissura parua: non ergo oportet, ut moueas ipsum cum manu et compressione omnino, imo pone super ipsum ex medicinis, quarum uenit rememoratio, post momentum illud quod conuenit loco: deinde stringatur strictura subtili.	 When therefore no curvature appears in its place nor does pain occur with your touch when you touch the bone with movement, nor does a weak great pain arise; then there is no fracture there, indeed it may be a curvature or a small cleft; therefore it is not necessary to move it with the hand and compression at all, but rather lay medicines upon it, whose memory comes after the appropriate time; then a ligature is tightened with subtle binding.
Et scias, quod locus quando arcuatur, et scinditur in duo, praeter quod accidant in eo satagiae, uerumtamen remouetur omnis pars a compari sua: tunc oportet tibi, ut incipias ab hora tua ad rectificationem eius, aequando ipsum antequam accidat ei apostema calidum.	 And know that when a place bows and splits into two, there occur stars (spicules) in it, yet all parts are separated from each other; then you must begin from your hour for its correction, by aligning it before abscess (pus) hot (comes).
Si autem accidat ei apostema calidum, tunc dimitte ipsum diebus aliquot, donec quiescat apoestema.	 If however a boil becomes hot, then let it be left for some days until the boil subsides.
Deinde aequa ipsum secundum quemcunque modum potest ex lenitate et ingenio.	 Then lance the abscess according to whatever method is possible with kindness and skill.
Et scias, quod restauratio eius, et ipsius aequatio, est facilior quam ossis, in quo accidunt satagiae.	 And know that the restoration of it (the abscess) and its equalization is easier than that of a bone, in which fractures occur.
Deinde stringe ipsum, secundum quod ueniet tibi rememoratio eius.	 Then tie it (the abscess) according to when you remember about it.
Si uero in osse sunt satagiae, tunc necessaria est extensio huius membri fracti ex duabus partibus, si manus sit, aut pes: aut cum manu tua, si membrum est paruum: aut cum duobus funibus, aut cum fune et manu.	 If however there are fractures in the bone, then extension of this fractured member from two parts is necessary, whether it is a hand or a foot; or with your own hand, if the member is small; or with two ropes, or with a rope and your hand.
Et sit positio tua qua ponis membrum super locum aequalem, secundum figuram suam naturalem, donec quando extenduntur partes membri fracti: tunc conare, ut redire facias illas additiones omni ingenio, et secundum quemcunque modum potes in locis suis: et caue secundum fortitudinem tuam, ne accidat super infirmum per operationem tuam dolor, neque laesio: et conare secundum fortitudinem tuam, ut applices unum duorum ossium cum socio suo, secundum meliores formas.	 And let your position be such when you place the member over an equal place according to its natural shape, until the parts of the fractured member extend; then strive to bring back those additions with all skill and in whatever way you can at their places: and beware according to your strength, lest pain occur in a weak person due to your operation, nor injury; and strive according to your strength to apply one of two bones with its partner, according to the best shapes.
Et oportet in illa hora, ut tentes et tangas ipsum manu tua.	 And it is necessary that at that hour you try and touch it (the fractured member) with your hand.
Si ergo uides illic aliquid diuersum, rectifica ipsum, et aequa illud per quantitatem tuae uirtutis.	 If therefore you see something different there, correct it and equalize it according to the quantity of your force.
Et caue extensionem uehementem, et compressionem fortem, sicut faciunt multi stolidorum.	 And beware of violent extension and strong compression, as many foolish ones do.
Multotiens enim faciunt accidere per operationem illam suam apostema calidum, aut contractionem in membro: sicut iam uidimus illud ex operationibus eorum multotiens.	 For many times they cause boils to appear due to their operation or a contraction in the member; as we have already seen from their operations many times.
Deinde annecte post aequationem, et decentem operationem, et stricturam illius membri, et quietem, et tranquillitatem: et mone infirmum super ipsum.	 Then attach after equalization, and a proper operation, and constriction of that member, and calmness, and peace; and warn the weak one about it.
Et fac ipsum cauere, ne moueat ipsum in hora suarum uigiliarum, et somni sui apud reuolutionem suam, et agitationem suam, et apud egestionem suam, et omnes motus suos ultima uirtute sua.	 Make him be careful not to move himself during his hours of vigil, and during the turning of his sleep, and during his agitations, and during his digestions, and all his movements with utmost strength.
Et ut caueat, ne sit positio membri positio cum qua sequatur dolor.	 Make him be careful that the position of a member will not follow pain.
Quod est, quia quando sentit in dispositione positionis membri dolorem, aut laesionem: tunc oportet, ut permutes ipsum ad dispositionem aliam ab illa cum qua non sentiat dolorem.	 Because when he feels pain or injury in the disposition of a member's position, then it is necessary to change his position into another that does not cause him pain.
Et caue cum illo, ut sit positio eius illa aequalis, recta: ut non accidat in membro tortuositas, quando restauratur.	 Be careful that his position is equal and straight so that it does not happen that there will be deformation in the member when it is restored.
Et qualitas stricturae membri fracti est, secundum quod narro.	 And the quality of the tightening of a broken member, as I said.
Scias, quod membra fracta diuersificantur in paruitate sua, et eorum magnitudine, et ipsorum forma.	 Know that broken members are diversified according to their size, and the magnitude of their parts, and their form.
Quae ergo ex eis sunt parua, sicut brachium, et digitus, et focile, et similia eis, tunc oportet, ut sit inuolutio panni mollis, subtilis.	 Therefore, those that are small, such as the arm, and finger, and tool, and similar to them, then it is necessary for there to be a soft, subtle wrapping of cloth around them.
Quae autem ex eis sunt grossa, sicut coxa, et crus, oportet ut sit in eis inuolutio lata, dura.	 But those that are large, such as the thigh and leg, it is necessary for there to be a wide, firm wrapping around them.
Quoniam ligamentum latum, connectit membrum magnum, et stringit ipsum ab omni parte strictura aequali, ita quod non ingreditur ipsum macula.	 Because a broad bandage connects a large member and tightly binds it from all sides with an equal tightness, so that no spot is left open.
Deinde incipe post euacuationem tuam ab aequatione ponere linimentum conueniens ad illud, in stuppa leni super locum fracturae ipsius.	 Then after your evacuation, begin to apply a suitable liniment on it, on a soft woolen cloth over the place of the fracture.
Deinde incipe inuoluere ligamentum super locum fracturae ipsius tribus inuolutionibus, aut quatuor, secundum quod meretur membrum: et stringe manum tuam parumper cum ligamento.	 Then begin to wrap the bandage around the place of the fracture three or four times, according to what the member deserves, and tighten your hand slightly with the bandage.
Deinde uade cum eo ad partem superiorem a loco fracturae, et stringe minus quam fuit strictura tua, qua strinxisti locum fractum.	 Then go with him to the upper part from the place of the fracture, and tighten less than your previous tightening that you had at the fractured place.
Deinde elonga te cum inuolutione a loco fracturae parumper, et mollifica stricturam paulatim, donec capias ex loco sano rem magnam.	 Then gradually extend yourself from the place of the fracture a little, and soften the constriction slowly, until you take out a large piece from a healthy place.
Deinde accipe uittam aliam, et inuolue eam iterum super locum fractum inuolutionibus.	 Then take another plaster and apply it again over the fractured place with folds.
Postea uade cum inuolutione ad partem inferiorem a fractura.	 Then go downwards with folds towards the lower part from the fracture.
Et sit operatio tua in strictura inuolutionis, et mollificatione eius, secundum quod diximus in inuolutione prima superiore.	 And let your operation be in the constriction of the fold and its softening, as we said in the first fold above.
Deinde pone inter inuolutiones ex stuppa leni, aut panno, cum quo aequetur tortuositas fracturae, si est in ea tortuositas: et si non, non ponas in ea aliquid.	 Then put between the folds from soft wool or cloth that corresponds to the twisting of the fracture if it is twisted: and if not, do not place anything there.
Deinde inuolue super ipsam uittam aliam.	 Then fold again over the other plaster.
Postea aequa super has inuolutiones astellas decenter factas statim, si non est in loco inflatio, neque apostema calidum.	 Then place stars evenly on these folds immediately, if there is no swelling or hot abscess.
Si autem in ea est inflatio, aut apostema: tunc pone super eam quod sedet illud apostema, et auferat inflationem: et dimitte eam aliquot diebus.	 If there is a swelling or an abscess there: then place on it what sits on that abscess and remove the swelling; and leave it for some days.
Deinde stringe super ipsam tunc astellas.	 Then tie the stars over it.
Et sint Astellae ex medietatibus cannae latae, rasae, formatae sapienter: aut sint ex ligno unde fiunt cribra, quae fiunt ex pino, aut geraid, id est, ramis palmae, aut calingi: et sit amplitudo omnis Astellae, secundum hanc formam, et hanc eandem figuram.	 And let the stars be from the middle parts of wide canes, shaved, well-formed: or let them be from wood where sieves are made, which are made from pine, fir, or palm branches, or boxwood: and let the width of each star be according to this form and this same shape.
Verumtamen oportet, ut Astella quae ponitur super ipsam tracturam, sit grossior et latior parumper, quam reliquae Astellae: et longitudo Astellae sit secundum quod licet membro ex magnitudine et paruitate.	 However, the star that is placed over the fracture should be slightly larger and wider than the other stars: and the length of the star should be according to what fits the limb in size and smallness.
Deinde stringe super Astellas cum uitta alia, secundum stricturam primam eandem.	 Then tie with another plaster over the stars according to the first constriction.
Deinde liga desuper cum filis decenter, secundum quod diximus de strictura: et est, ut sit strictura tua super locum fracturae plus: et quanto plus elongatur a fractura sit, strictura minor.	 Then tie above with cords evenly, as we said about the constriction: and let your constriction be over the fracture place more: and the more it is extended from the fracture, the less the constriction.
Et oportet, ut sint fila media in grossitudine et subtilitate, et sint ex lino molli.	 And it is necessary that the threads are medium-sized and fine, and they should be made from soft linen.
Quoniam si fila sunt grossa, sicut uidi ex operatione stolidorum ponentium fila sua ex chordis lini tortis, est error magnus: quoniam cadit strictura cum eis extra qualitatem.	 If the threads are thick, as I have seen stupid people using twisted threads of coarse linen in their operations, it is a great mistake: because the constriction falls out with them beyond its quality.
Et fila subtilia iterum non conueniunt: quoniam tu non consequeris per stricturam cum eis illud quod uis.	 And fine threads again do not agree: because you will not achieve with them by constriction what you want.
Et non oportet, ut sit inter astellam et astellam minus quam digitus.	 It is not necessary that there be less than a finger's breadth between the astellae (metal needles or pins used in surgery).
Quod si laeditur infirmus per extremitates astellarum post stricturam in locis sanis: tunc pone sub eis ex stuppa leni, aut lana carminata, donec nihil laedatur ex illo.	 If the sick person is hurt by the tips of the astellae after constriction in healthy places: then place beneath them with soft wool or camouflaged wool until nothing is hurt from it.
Quando autem est fractura cum uulnere, et accidit disruptio in cute, ego ueniam cum rememoratione eius in capitulo secundum singularitatem.	 When there is a fracture with wound, and it happens that the break-up occurs on the skin, I shall come again with its reminder to the second chapter of singularity (specific cases).
Et scias, quod non omne membrum fractum oportet ut stringatur cum astellis a primo die.	 And know that not every broken member must be bound with pins from the first day.
Quod est, quia membrum quando est magnum, non oportet ut ponas superipsum astellas, nisi post quinque dies, aut septem, aut plus, secundum securitatem tuam ab euentu apostematis calidi.	 That is, because when the member is large, it is not necessary to place needles above it, unless after five days or seven or more, according to your safety from the occurrence of an abscess from a hot wound.
Et iste est modus emplastrorum, quibus restaurabant antiqui, quae ponuntur super fracturam et dislocationem.	 This is the method of plasters which the ancients used to restore that are placed on a fracture and dislocation.
¶ Modus Emplastri communis abbreuiati, restaurans fracturam, conueniens pluribus complexionibus, praecipue mulieribus, et pueris: quoniam est ex eo super quod non uincit calor, neque frigus.	 Common emplaster method abbreviated, restoring the fracture, suitable for multiple temperaments, especially women and children, because it is from that which heat does not conquer nor cold.
Et est, ut accipias ex puluere molendini, et est medulla farinae quae pendet in parietibus molendini apud motum molae: et conficias ipsum sicut est, praeter quod cribelles ipsum cum albugine oui: et pone confectionem eius non spissam, neque subtilem.	 And it is that you should take from the flour mill dust, and it is the marrow of the wheat that hangs on the walls of the mill near the movement of the grinder; and prepare it in this way, except that you sieve it with egg white; and place its mixture not thick, nor thin.
Deinde utere eo.	 Then use it.
¶ Modus Emplastri alius, restaurantis fracturam, et dislocationem, et torsionem.	 Another method of plastering (bandage), for setting a broken bone, and reducing a dislocation, and twisting.
Recipe almess, et laudani, et acaciae, et enulae, et mugath: et suc, omnium ana ʒ X myrrhae, et aloes amborum ana ʒ V et alethil ʒ XX terantur omnia, et cribellentur, et misceantur cum aqua alethil: aut cum albugine oui, si complexio infirmi est calefacta.	 Take almess, laudanum, acacia, enula, and mugath: and steep all of them in ten parts of myrrh, and five parts of both aloes, and twenty parts of alethil: grind everything, sift it, and mix with the water of alethil; or with sheep's milk whey if the bandage is heated for a sick person.
Deinde utere hoc emplastro.	 Then use this plaster.
Nam ipsum est bonae compositionis, restaurat ossa fracta uelociter, et confert pluribus hominibus.	 For it is of good composition, it quickly sets broken bones, and benefits many people.
¶ Modus Emplastri alius, quod etiam confert fracturae et torsioni.	 Another method of plastering (bandage), which also benefits a fracture and twisting.
Recipe mugath, et mess, et alteae albae, omnium ana ʒ X myrrhae, et aloes amborum ana ʒ V acaciae ʒ VI boli armeni ʒ XX terantur omnia contritione multa, et cribellentur, et conficiantur cum aqua, aut albugine oui: et administrentur.	 Take mugath, mess, white alteae, all in ten parts of myrrh, and five parts of both aloes, six parts of Armenian pitch in twenty parts: grind everything well, sift it, and make with water or sheep's milk whey: and administer.
¶ Modus Emplastri ad iuncturas, et ossa separata ex locis suis: et sedat dolorem accidentem eis, et scissuram ossis, et fracturam.	 Another method of plastering (bandage) for joints and bones separated from their places: it relieves the pain that occurs to them, and stops the splitting of the bone, and the break.
Sumatur lana succida, et submergatur in aceto, et oleo decocto: et ponatur super locum.	 Take raw wool, immerse it in vinegar, and boil it in oil: place it over the site.
Et in hoc quidem Emplastro non est uirtus restaurationis, sed est bonum in sedatione apostematis calidi: et expellit dolores proprie.	 And indeed, there is no virtue of restoration in this plaster, but it is good for the treatment of a hot abscess: and it expels pains properly.
¶ Modus Emplastri, quod restaurat os fractum.	 Another method of plastering (bandage), which restores a broken bone.
Sume folia fici surdi, et folia papaueris syluestris: et tere omnia, et fac emplastrum ex utrisque.	 Take leaves of the deaf fig, and leaves of wild papaver: grind everything, and make a plaster from both.
¶ Modus Emplastri abbreuiati, administrati apud restaurationem fracturae ossis: et quando tu uis resolutionem residui apostematis.	 Another shortened method of plastering (bandage), used for the restoration of a broken bone: and when you wish for the resolution of the remaining abscess.
Recipe radicis alteae, et camomillae, et florum uiolarum, et farinae herbi, omnium ana partem unam: terantur omnia, et conficiantur cum uino, si non est membrum calefactum.	 Make a mixture of the root of althea, chamomile, marshmallow flowers, and barley flour, taking equal parts of each: grind all and make it with wine, unless the member is already heated.
Si uero est calefactum, tunc confice illud cum aqua coriandri humidi, aut cum aqua, et utere eo.	 If it is already heated, then use that mixture with coriander water or just water.
¶ Modus Emplastri alius fortioris in resolutione, quam istud primum, quando accidit apostema durum apud restaurationem membri.	 A stronger method of plaster for resolving a hard abscess during the restoration of a member.
Recipe radicis alteae, et seminis lini, et balaustiae, et melliloti, et samsuci, et floris uiolarum, et camomillae, omnium ana, partem unam, terantur omnia, et conficiantur cum aqua salicis, aut cum aqua dulci, aut cum uino.	 Make a mixture of the root of althea, linseed, beechwood, medick, samsuc, marshmallow flowers, chamomile, taking equal parts of each: grind all and make it with willow water, or sweet water, or wine.
Totum illud secundum caliditatem membri, et quietem caloris eius.	 Apply the mixture to the member according to its warmth and the calmness of the heat.
Hippocrates uero non dixit in libro suo, quod ponatur super membrum fractum apud restaurationem eius, nisi caerotum factum ex caera, et oleo: non aliud: et narrauit, ut sit medium inter grossitudinem et subtilitatem.	 However, Hippocrates did not say in his book that it should be placed on a broken member during its restoration, except for a plaster made from beeswax and oil: nothing else; and he said it should be of a medium consistency between thickness and subtlety.
Galeno autem uisum est, ut ponantur super membrum fractum apud restaurationem eius res, in quibus est exiccatio caliditatis, sicut myrrha, et aloes et olibanum, et similia eis ex eis quae narrauimus.	 Galen, however, seemed to think that something should be placed on a broken member during its restoration which has the ability to draw out heat, such as myrrh, aloe and frankincense, and similar substances from what we have mentioned.
¶ Modus Emplastri quod confert ad laesionem et dolorem.	 A method of plaster for treating injuries and pain.
Recipe mugath, et ciceris, et capillorum hominis incisorum, aut pennae auis, et alteae, et salis partes aequales: terantur, et cribellentur, et conficiantur: et fiat ex eo emplastrum.	 Make a plaster from mugath, chickpeas, cut human hair or bird feathers, althea, and salt in equal parts: grind them all into powder, and make the plaster out of it.
Quantitas autem secundum quam oportet, ut remaneat ligatura, deinde soluatur, est, ut consideres tunc, si non accidit infirmo dolor, neque pruritus, neque mouetur os fractum a loco suo: tunc non resoluas ipsum diebus multis.	 The amount of plaster that should be used, so that the bandage remains in place, is as follows: you should then loosen it if there is no persistent pain, itching, or the bone moves from its place: then do not loosen it for several days.
Quod si accidat ei in loco pruritus uehemens, aut dolor inquietans, aut inflatio: tunc propera, et solue in hora ipsum, et aufer emplastrum ab eo: et accipe pannum lenem, aut spongiam marinam lenem, humidam: et submerge eam in aqua tepida, et ablue cum ea locum, donec quiescat pruritus, et sedetur dolor.	 If it happens to him at the place that there is violent itching, or troubling pain, or swelling: then hurry and dissolve it in an hour himself, and remove the plaster from him: and take soft cloth, or sea sponge, moist: and submerge it in warm water, and wash with it the place until the itching subsides, and the pain sits still.
Deinde dimitte membrum quiescere una hora.	 Then allow the limb to rest for an hour.
Deinde pone super ipsum lanam succidam, submersam in aceto et oleo, aut oleo rosato: et liga super ipsum nocte una, donec sis securus ab apostemate calido, et quiescat inflatio membri, et remoueatur dolor eius.	 Then place upon him a piece of flax soaked in vinegar and oil, or rose oil: and bind over it at night until you are sure of the disappearance of the hot inflammation, and the swelling rests, and the pain is removed from it.
Deinde itera ipsum ad stricturam subtilem, et emplastrum paruum: et non stringas ipsum constrictione tua prima, et subtilia cum eo, donec sanetur.	 Then proceed with a subtle bind and a small plaster: do not bind it tightly at first with your tight bind, but gently with the thin one until it is healed.
Quod si uides, quod apostema, et rubedo, et dolor, et inflatio, et omnia accidentia iam remota sunt penitus, et indiges emplastro et strictura, tunc itera illud sicut fecisti in primis aequaliter.	 If you see that the abscess, redness, pain, swelling, and all other symptoms have been completely removed, and you need a plaster and bind, then proceed with it as you did at first equally.
Quod si non accidit membro aliquid ex eis quae diximus, tune non soluas ipsum, nisi post tres dies, aut quatuor, aut quinque, aut septem.	 If nothing of what we mentioned happens to the limb, then do not dissolve it before three, four, five or seven days.
Et quando que dimittitur uiginti diebus totum illud, secundum quod apparet tibi ex solutione membri, sicut diximus, donec quando adhaeret fractura, et approximat coagulatio carnis super eam: adde etiam tunc in strictura plus quam strictura tua prima tota: et adde etiam in ingrossatione cibi infirmi, secundum quod praecessit rememoratio eius.	 And when it is discharged after twenty days, according to what appears to you from the dissolution of the limb, as we said, until when there remains a fracture and adherence of coagulated flesh on it: add also in the bind more than your first bind, and also in the thickening of food, according to what was mentioned before its remembrance.
Si autem uides locum fracturae iam exiccari, et extenuari plus quam oportet: tunc scias, quod nutrimentum prohibetur peruenire ad ipsum.	 But if you see the place of fracture already to dry out and become thinner than necessary: then know that nutrition is prevented from reaching it.
Embroca ergo ipsum cum aqua tepida apud omnem uicem qua soluis ipsum, et sit illud in omnibus tribus diebus, et alleuia stricturam parumper.	 Boil the ointment with warm water in every place where you dissolve it, and let it be for three days, and loosen slightly the stricture (or narrow passage).
Per hanc ergo operationem currit ad membrum nutrimentum, et sanatur uelociter.	 By this procedure, nourishment flows to the limb, and it heals quickly.
Illud autem quod faciunt stolidi restauratores ex fractura membri uice alia, quando non restauratur in primis, secundum quod oportet, et restauratur secundum tortuositatem, est error ex operatione eorum, et timor magnus: et si esset rectum, dixissent illud antiqui in libris suis, et operati fuissent cum eo.	 What foolish restorers do instead of a limb fracture, when it is not restored as it should be at first, and it is restored according to its curvature, is an error due to their operation, and there is great fear: And if it were correct, the ancients would have said so in their books, and they would have operated with it.
Et ego non uidi alicubi eorum uestigium in illo omnino, et rectius est, ut non fiat illud.	 And I have not seen anywhere the trace of such a thing, and it is more correct that it should not be done.
¶ De factura accidente in capite.	 Chapter on making an incision in the head.
Caput III.	 Chapter III.
Species fracturae sunt diuersae, et figurae eius multae: et caussae eius sunt distinctae.	 Types of fractures are diverse, and their shapes numerous; their causes are distinguished.
Nam ex fractura est quae fit a percussione cum ense: et percussio aufert os totum usquequo peruenit ad siphac, quod est sub osse, sicut facit axia in ligno: et propter illud nominatur haec species fracturae Axialis.	 For from a fracture is that which occurs by striking with an edge: and striking removes the bone entirely to the extent it reaches the siphac (a soft tissue beneath the bone), just as an ax does in wood; and for this reason, this type of fracture is called Axial.
Aut ensis incidit quiddam ossis, et incidit faciem eius, et non penetrat incisio usque ad ultimum eius: et nominatur haec species fracturae Kalaan, id est, Leuatio absolute.	 Or the edge of a sword cuts some bone and only cuts its surface, but does not penetrate through the incision to the end; and this type of fracture is called Calcani, that is, Absolute Lever.
Et est uulnus duarum fracturarum, aut magnum, aut paruum.	 And there are two types of wounds in fractures, either large or small.
Et ex fractura est, quae est contritio, aut attritio: et caussa eius est percussio cum lapide, aut casus super lapidem, aut eis similia.	 And from a fracture is that which is crushing or grinding; and its cause is striking with a stone, or falling on a stone, or similar things.
Et haec fractura est etiam aut penetrans, quae iam appropinquat panniculo, quod est sub osse: aut est in facie ossis: et est uulnus harum duarum fracturarum etiam aut paruum, aut magnum.	 And this fracture is also penetrating, which already approaches the panniculus (a fatty tissue beneath the skin), which is under the bone; or it is on the surface of the bone: and the wound of these two types of fractures is also either small or large.
Et ex fractura est, quae est occulta in osse in subtilitate capilli: et est fissura parua, et propter illud nominatur haec species fracturae Capillaris.	 And from a fracture, which is hidden within the bone in subtlety like hair, is a small split, and because of this it is called this kind of fracture Capillary.
Et ex eis est fractura, quae fit a casu, aut percussione lapidis, et eis similium, quae faciunt ingredi laminam ossis ad interiora, et fit loco concauitas: sicut accidit caldariis aeris, quando occurrit eis percussio, et ingreditur pars eorum ad interiora.	 And from these (kinds of fractures) is a fracture that happens by accident or striking with a stone, and those like them that make the bone plate to penetrate into the inside, and it becomes concave at that place: just as it happens to the caldarii (metalworkers) of iron, when they are struck and part of them penetrates into the inside.
Et plurimum quidem fit illud in capitibus humidorum ossium, sicut sunt capita puerorum.	 Most certainly, this happens in moist skull bones, such as those of children.
Et fiunt omnibus istis speciebus fracturae satagiae separatae, et ego ueniam cum rememoratione illius totius in loco suo.	 All these kinds of fractures are made with sawing and separation, and I will come back to the subject in its place.
Et cognoscimus omnes has species fracturae per detectionem super eam, et inquisitionem earum cum tentis, et ablationem carnium corruptarum, quae sunt super eas.	 We recognize all these kinds of fractures by examination over it, and investigation of them with tests, and removal of the corrupted flesh that is over them.
Species uero Capillaris cognoscitur per hoc, quod detegitur super os, et abstergitur, et linitur super ipsum cum encaustro: fractura enim apparet nigra.	 The Capillary kind is recognized by this, that it shows on the bone, is scraped off, and a thin layer is laid over it with pitch: for the fracture appears black.
In curatione autem fracturae, considera in primis accidentia infirmi: tunc si uides ex accidentibus quod significet significatione manifesta super timorem, sicut uomitus cholerae, et extensio, et amissio intellectus, et abscisio uocis, et syncopis, et febris acuta, et egressus oculorum, et rubedo eorum, et similia eis ex accidentibus in pluribus dispositionibus, proculdubio non sanatur: et si uides accidentia non terrentia te, et speras salutem: tunc incipe curationem eius.	 In treating a fracture, first consider the condition of the sick person: if you see from the conditions that it indicates a clear sign of fear, such as cholera vomiting, extension, loss of intellect, absence of voice, fainting, acute fever, discharge of eyes, redness of them and similar things from other conditions in various dispositions, there is certainly no recovery: and if you see the conditions not frightening to you, and hope for health, then begin its treatment.
Quod est, si uenit ad te uulneratus in primis cum uulneratur: et est illud in diebus hyemis, tunc oportet, ut studeas in ablatione ossis ante diem quartumdecimum secundum omnem dispositionem.	 If someone comes to you wounded in the first place when he is wounded: and it is in winter days, then it is necessary that you study in the removal of the bone before the 14th day according to all dispositions.
Et si est in diebus aestatis, tunc oportet, ut properes remouere os ante diem septimum, antequam corrumpatur quod est sub osse ex panniculo, et accidant illa accidentia quae narrauimus.	 If it is in the days of summer, then it is necessary that you hasten to remove the bone before the seventh day, before it becomes corrupt beneath the bone from the fat, and such accidents happen as we have described.
Quod si fractura ossis iam peruenit ad panniculum tangentem cerebrum, et est cum minutiis, et attractione: tunc oportet, ut incidas partem comminutam, et attritam, secundum quod narro tibi.	 If the fracture of the bone has already reached the fat touching the brain and is accompanied by fragments and traction: then it is necessary that you cut the broken and smoothed part, as I have told you.
Et est, ut radas caput uulnerati: et detege super os secundum quemcunque modum possibile est tibi: et secundum figuram uulneris, et quod leue est super infirmum.	 And it is to be shaved the head of the wounded: and dig on top of the bone as much as possible for you: and according to the shape of the wound, and what is light on what is weak.
Quod si accidat tibi apud detectionem ossis fluxus sanguinis, aut apostema calidum: tunc oppone ei cum eo quod oportet.	 If it happens to you during the digging of the bone, a flow of blood or a hot abscess: then oppose it with what is necessary.
Et est, ut impleas locum cum pannis infusis in uino, et oleo rosato: et facias quiescere uulnus, donec sedetur apostema, et sis securus a fluxu sanguinis.	 And it is to fill the place with rags soaked in wine and rose oil: and let the wound rest until the abscess settles down, and be safe from the flow of blood.
Deinde incipe in curatione ossis, et ablatione eius.	 Then begin in the treatment of the bone, and its removal.
Et illud fit secundum unum duorum modorum.	 And that is done according to one of two methods.
Modus quidem unus est, ut incidas os cum Incisorio strictae aciei: et haec est forma eius.	 The first method is to cut the bone with a knife having a narrow blade: and this is its shape.
Dende administra Incisorium aliud post Incisorum latius eo parumper: et haec est forma eius.	 Then administer another knife, narrower still: and this is its shape.
Deinde administra etiam Incisorium aliud latius etiam quam secundum.	 Then administer yet another knife, wider still.
Et modus secundus est, ut sit apud te numerus Incisoriorum diuersorum: quorum quaedam sint latiora quibusdam, et quaedam eorum breuiora quibusdam: et sint in ultimo acuitatis extremitatum suarum, et sint ex ferro indo, aut fuled: et utere facilitate in percussione super Incisorium, ut non concutiat caput, et laedat ipsum.	 The second method is that there should be with you a number of different knives, some of which are wider than others, and some of which are shorter than others: and they should have their edges at the extremities sharpened, and made of steel or iron that has been hardened: and use them with ease in striking the knife, so as not to concuss the head and injure it.
Si autem os est forte, durum: tunc oportet, ut perfores in circumitu eius, antequam tu administres Incisoria, cum Terebris quae nominantur Terebra non profundantia: et non nominantur ita, nisi quoniam ipsa non pertranseunt terminum ossis carnei ad illud, quod est post ipsum: propterea, quod Terebro est extremitas rotunda super illud, quod est sub capite eius acuto, similis margini, et circulus paruus prohibet submergi, et pertransire spissitudinem ossis.	 If the bone is hard and firm: then it is necessary that you bore around its circumference before you administer Incisoria, with Terebris which are named Terebra not penetrating deeply; they are not called so because they do not pass beyond the bone's marrow to what is behind it, since the tip of the Terebra is rounded above what is under its head and sharp, like an edge, and a small circle prevents it from being submerged and passing through the bone's thickness.
Et conuenit tibi, ut accipias ex istis Terebris numerum multum, quorum unumquodque conueniat quantitati spissitudinis ossis, donec praesens sit tibi omni craneo Terebrum: cuius extremitatis acutae quantitas in longitudine et breuitate sit, secundum quantitatem spissitudinis illius cranei.	 It is necessary that you take a large number of Terebris from these, one for each thickness of the bone, until there is Terebra for every part of the skull; whose sharp tip's length and width should be according to the thickness of the said skull.
Et haec est forma trium specierum Terebrorum, uel Trepanorum.	 And this is the form of three kinds of Terebrums or Trepans.
Qualitas autem perforandi in circumitu ossis fracti, est: ut ponas Terebrum super os, et reuoluas ipsum digitis tuis, donec scias, os iam penetratum esse.	 The quality of boring around the broken bone is: that you place a Terebra on the bone and rotate it with your fingers until you know the bone has been penetrated.
Deinde permuta Terebrum ad locum alium, et pone quod est inter omne foramen quantitatem grossitudinis radii, aut circiter illud.	 Then change the Terebra to another place, and place what is between every hole of a size corresponding to the thickness of the radius or approximately that.
Deinde incide cum Incisoriis quod est inter omne foramen ex osse: et fac illud subtilius quam potes super illud ex fine leuitatis, sicut diximus, donec eradices os, aut manu tua, aut cum aliquo alio ex quibusdam instrumentis, quae parasti ad illud: sicut tenaliae, et forpices subtiles.	 Then cut with the Incisoria between every hole from the bone: and make it thinner than possible above that from the edge of softness, as we said, until you extract the bone, either with your hand or with some other tools which you have prepared for this purpose: such as tenaliae, and subtle forpices.
Et oportet, ut caueas omni cautela, ne tangat Terebrum, aut Incisorium aliquid ex siphac.	 And it is necessary that you be careful to avoid with the greatest care that the Terebra or the Incisoria touch any part of the siphac [a type of horn used for surgical instruments].
Cum ergo circumieris os perforando, et separatum fuerit a siphac, si fuerit continuum cum eo, et extraxeris ipsum, oportet ut radas, et aeques extremitatem eius quod remanet in osse cum instrumento alio simili Incisorio.	 When you are boring around the bone and separating it from the siphac [horn], if it is continuous with it and you extract it, it is necessary that you smooth and even its remaining part on the bone with another similar tool, like an Incisoria.
Verumtamen oportet, ut sit tenuis et subtilis magis aliis Incisoriis.	 It is necessary that it [the instrument] should be thin and subtle more than other cutting instruments.
Quod si remanet aliquid ex ossibus paruis, et satagiae: tunc accipe ea cum facilitate, cum eo quod est apud te ex instrumentis.	 If something remains of small bones or cartilage: then take it with ease, along with what you have at hand from your instruments.
Deinde cura uulnus post illud cum liciniis, et unguentis quae diximus.	 Then, care for the wound afterwards with lints and the ointments that I mentioned.
Et modus alius operationis est facilis, prorsus longinquus a timore: quem dixit Galenus, et laudauit ipsum laude magna: et iste est sermo eius.	 Another method of operation is easy, completely free from fear: which Galen said and praised greatly: and this is his saying.
Necese est tibi in primis, ut incipias detegere partem ossis ex loco, in quo fractura est uehementior, et manifestior: donec quando detexeris illam partem, et posueris sub eo extremitatem huius Incisorii lenticularis, cuius haec est forma.	 It is necessary for you first to begin by uncovering the bone fragment from the place where the fracture is more violent and visible: until when you have uncovered that part and placed under it the end of this curved cutter, which has this form.
Et pars lenticularis, lenis non incidit aliquid: et pars acuta eius in duabus lateribus eius uadens in longitudinem, sicut uides: ut sit pars lenticularis innixa ad siphac, facie eius incidente acuta in osse.	 The curved part of the cutter does not cut anything: and the sharp end of it on both sides going along its length, as you see: so that the curved part may be fixed to the handle, its sharp edge falling on the bone.
Deinde percute super Incisorium a parte una cum malleo paruo, donec incidas totum os cum facilitate, sicut reuoluitur: et tu sis securus ex panniculo, quod non accidat in eo accidens, quod timeas prorsus.	 Then strike on the cutter from one side with a small hammer until you have cut through the whole bone easily, as it is turned: and be careful that the cloth does not slip off what happens accidentally, which you should fear completely.
Et si medicans non esset stultior hominum, et magis ignarus eius, nec esset dormiens, tunc si remaneret aliquid annexum ossi ex panniculo in quibusdam locis, incideret ipsum ab eo cum extremitate incisorii lenticularis ipsius, et liberaret ipsum ab eo cum facilitate.	 And if the physician were not more foolish than men, and less ignorant of it, nor asleep, then if something remained attached to the bone from the cloth in certain places, he would cut it off with the end of the curved cutter and free it easily.
Liberatur enim ab eo sine nocumento, et absque timore.	 It is freed from it without harm and without fear.
Et si fractura ossis non penetret usque ad panniculum, et illud quod abscinditur ab osse est facies eius, et remanent in ipso asperitas et satagiae subtiles: tunc oportet, ut radas illam asperitatem, et eradices illas satagias cum rasoriis subtilibus ex quibus praeparasti numerum diuersarum quantitatum, ut sit tibi possibile administrare ex eis in omni loco conuenientiora eorum, et rectiora ipsorum, secundum illud ad quod perducit te operatio, et ipsum os fractum, et figura eius.	 If the bone fracture does not penetrate to the cloth, and what is cut off from the bone is its face, and roughness and subtle cartilage remain in it: then it is necessary that you scrape away the roughness, and excavate the cartilages with sharp scissors of various quantities which you have prepared, so that it may be possible for you to apply them more appropriately in every place according to what the operation leads you, and the fractured bone, and its figure.
Et oportet, ut administres in rasione tua, qua in primis radis os, latius illorum rasoriorum.	 It is necessary that you administer [the operation] according to your reason, firstly by sawing the bone, more widely with these retractors.
Deinde utere post ipsum subtiliore eo.	 Then use a finer instrument after that.
Et non cesses facere illud secundum continuitatem, donec peruenias ad administrandum tenuius, et subtilius eorum omnium.	 Do not cease to do it in continuity until you reach administering [it] thinner and finer of all of them.
In unaquaque autem fissurarum reliquarum paruarum capillarium, et fractura subtili, oportet ut administres curam, secundum illud quod perducit ad rectificationem eius.	 In every small remaining crack or fine fracture, it is necessary that you apply care, according to what leads to its correction.
Et est res quae non occultatur super omnem, cui in hac arte est quodlibet studium, et stetit super illud quod scripsimus, et ostendimus in fracturis magnis.	 And there is a matter that is not hidden upon all [things], to which any study in this art stands, and it has stood over what we have written and shown in large fractures.
Si autem panniculus detectus retinetur, quando tu eradicas os: tunc oportet, ut accipias pannum lini, secundum quantitatem uulneris, et submerge ipsum in oleo rosa, et pone ipsum super orificium uulneris.	 If a piece of flesh is detected and retained when you are removing bone: then it is necessary that you take linen cloth, according to the size of the wound, and immerse it in rose oil, and place it over the opening of the wound.
Deinde accipe pannum alium duplicatum, aut triplicatum, et submerge ipsum in uino et oleo rosa, et pone ipsum super pannum primum: et fac illud quam facilius potes super illud, ut non grauetur siphac.	 Then take another double or triple piece of linen cloth, immerse it in wine and rose oil, and place it on the first one; do what you can easily over it, so as not to burden the wound.
Deinde administra supra ipsum ligamentum latum: et non stringas ipsum, nisi per quantitatem quae teneat uulnus tantum: et dimitte ipsum cum hac cura die uno, aut diebus duobus, donec sis securus ab apostemate calido.	 Then administer a wide ligature over it; do not tie it, unless to the size that holds the wound only; and release it with this care for one day or two days until you are secure from warm inflammation.
Deinde solue ipsum, et administra post illud medicinas cum quibus est superflua siccitas: sicut radices lilii, et farina herbi, et puluis thuris, et aristolochia, et similia eis: et est, ut facias ex istis medicinis puluerem, qui puluerizetur super uulnus sicut sunt siccae.	 Then dissolve it [the ligation], and administer after that medications with which there is excessive dryness; such as the roots of garlic, and grain of herb, and frankincense powder, and aristolochia, and similar ones; and it is to make a powder from these medications, which will be applied to the wound like those [medications] that are dry.
Et uniuersaliter administra in illo omnem medicinam de proprietate cuius est ut abstergat, et non mordicet.	 And universally administer all medication in it of the property which is to purify and not corrode [the wound].
Et caue secundum tuam uirtutem, ut uulnus in curatione tua sit limpidum: neque sit in ea sordes unguenti, neque sordicies.	 And be careful according to your virtue, that the wound in your treatment is clean: neither let there be dirt of ointment, nor dirtiness.
Neque dimittas uirus aggregari in eo omnino: quoniam quando uirus aggregatur super panniculum cerebri, corrumpit eum, et putrefacit ipsum, et accidit super infirmum post illud malicia magna: et iam accidit in siphac capitis, cum mundificatur ab eo os, praecipue quando negligitur cura eius, nigredo in superficie eius.	 Do not allow pus to accumulate on it at all: because when pus gathers upon the brain tissue, it corrupts it and makes it putrefy, and afterward great harm occurs to the sick person after that; and already it has happened on the scalp of the head, when the bone is cleansed by him, especially when the care for it is neglected, a blackness appears on its surface.
Considera ergo tunc, si accidunt infirmo accidentia quae diximus, scias, quia est pernitiosum proculdubio.	 Therefore, if the accidents that I have mentioned occur to the sick person, know that it is certainly dangerous (or fatal).
Et si nigredo non accidit, nisi a medicina quae ponitur super ipsum, et est in uirtute illius medicinae, ut faciat illam nigredinem: tunc oportet, ut accipias ex melle partem unam, ex oleo rosato partes tres, et linias cum eis pannum.	 And if the blackness does not occur except from the medicine placed on him and it is in the virtue of that medicine to make it black: then you should take one part from honey and three parts from rose oil, and anoint it with them.
Deinde pone ipsum super siphac: postea cura ipsum cum speciebus curationis quae conueniunt, donec sanetur.	 Then place it on the scalp; afterward take care of it with appropriate remedies for healing until it is healed.
¶ De restauratione Nasi quando frangitur.	 Chapter on the restoration of the nose when broken.
Caput IIII.	 Chapter IV.
Scias, quod non franguntur ex Naso nisi duae partes eius superiores simul, aut una earum: propterea, quod ipse sunt duo ossa: quoniam inferius eius est cartilaginosum, non frangitur, et non accidit ei nisi attritio, et tortuositas, et simitas.	 Know that the nose is not broken except for two of its upper parts simultaneously, or one of them: because they are two bones; since below it is cartilaginous, it does not break, and harm such as attrition, twisting, or swelling does not occur to it unless there is attrition, twisting, or inflammation.
Si frangitur una duarum partium eius, tunc oportet, ut intromittas digitum paruum in foramen Nasi, et aeques illam fracturam digito tuo indice, et pollice deforis, donec redeat Nasus super figuram suam naturalem: et fiat illud arte, cum facilitate.	 If one of the two parts is broken, then you should insert a small finger into the nostril and align the fracture with your index and thumb fingers from outside until the nose returns to its normal shape: and do this skillfully, easily.
Et caue, ne accidat per operationem tuam illam super infirmum dolor.	 And be careful that no pain occurs to the sick person through your operation.
Quod si fractura est in superiore parte Nasi, et non perueniat ad illam digitus: tunc oportet, ut aequetur extremitate radii, in quo sit grossitudo parua.	 If a fracture is in the upper part of the nose, and it cannot be reached by a finger: then, it should be adjusted at the end of the radius, where there is a small swelling.
Si uero fractura est in duabus partibus, tunc fac simile illius: et propera cum restauratione eius in die primo fracturae, si est possibile.	 If [the injury] happens to be in two parts, then make it similar [to the other side]: and advance with its restoration on the first day of the fracture, if it is possible.
Et si non, tunc post diem septimum, aut decimum apud quietem apostematis calidi.	 And if not, then after the seventh or tenth day, at a place quiet for cauteries of warm water.
Deinde intromitte in extremitate Nasi licinium ex panno lini, si fractura est in parte una: aut intromite duo licinia si fractura est in duabus partibus: et sit in licinio grossitudo tantae quantitatis, quae impleat foramen Nasi.	 Then insert a piece of flax from linen cloth into the end of the nose if the fracture is in one part: or insert two pieces if the fracture is in two parts: and there should be a bulge of such size on the flax that it fills the nostril opening.
Et dixerunt quidam antiquorum restauratorum, ut infundantur licinia in butyro, et permutentur omni die.	 And some of the ancients who were restorers said that flax should be soaked in butter and changed every day.
Illud uero non uidetur mihi, imo oportet, ut infundatur licinium in albugine oui, confecto cum puluere molendini.	 But I do not see this [method] as good, rather it should be soaked in egg white made with flour mill powder.
Deinde dimitte licinium, donec firmetur os, et induretur cartilago.	 Then release the flax when the bone has hardened and the cartilage has become hard.
Et quandoque intromittitur in Nasum loco licinii penna anseris, postquam inuoluitur super ipsam pannus lenis: et fit, quod ipsa tenet fracturam Nasi uehementius, et ut non prohibeatur infirmus ab inspiratione.	 Sometimes a feather of a goose is inserted into the nose in place of the flax, after soft cloth has been placed over it: and this holds the nasal fracture more firmly, and prevents the weak from being prevented from breathing.
Et non est haec res necessaria.	 And this is not necessary.
Si uis, fac illud: et si uis, fac licinia.	 If you want, do it: if you don't want, do it with flax.
Quod si accidat Naso iterum dum operaris apostema calidum, emplastra nasum cum caeroto, aut cum coto infuso in oleo rosato, aut modico ex dyaquilon.	 If the nose again develops a cautery while working on an abscess, pack the nose with linen soaked in tar, or with pitch infused in rose oil, or with a little turpentine.
Si autem non accidit apostema calidum, tunc oportet, ut emplastres ipsum cum farina sisami, et puluere thuris confecti cum albugine oui.	 But if it does not develop a hot cautery, then the nose should be packed with flour from sesame seeds and frankincense powder mixed with egg white.
Deinde pone super ipsum stuppam lenem, et non liges Nasum cum aliquo omnino.	 Then place a soft cloth on top of it (the wound), and do not tie the nose with anything at all.
Si uero franguntur ossa Nasi fractura parua, aut comminuuntur, tunc oportet, ut scindas super ea, et extrahas ipsa cum instrumentis quae conueniunt eis.	 If however the nose bones are broken in a small fracture or ground down, then it is necessary that you make an incision over them and extract them with instruments suitable for the purpose.
Deinde sue scissuram, et cura ipsum cum eo quod incarnat, et consolidat ex emplastris conuenientibus ad illud, uel unguentis.	 Then either make an incision and take care of it with the one that coagulates and consolidates with plasters suitable for that purpose, or with ointments.
Quod si accidat inter Nasum uulnus, tunc oportet, ut cures ipsum cum liciniis: et administres cannulam de plumbo, donec sanetur.	 If it should happen that a wound occurs between the nose, then it is necessary to treat it with linen cloths, and to administer a lead cannula until healed.
¶ De restauratione Mandibulae inferioris, quando disrumpitur.	 Chapter on the restoration of the lower jaw when broken.
Caput V.	 Chapter V.
Quando disrumpitur Mandibula inferior, et fractura eius non est cum uulnere: conspice tunc si est fractura eius deforis tantum, et non frangitur in duo, et curuatur ad interiora: tunc cognitio eius est facilis.	 When the lower jaw is disrupted and the fracture is not with a wound: then observe whether its fracture is only outside and it does not break into two and bends towards the interior: then its recognition is easy.
Oportet ergo, si est fractura eius in parte dextra, ut intromittas digitum indicem sinistrae in os infirmi: similiter si fractura est in mandibula sinistra, tunc intromitte indicem manus dextrae: et impelle cum eo gibbositatem fracturae deintus cum facilitate ad exteriora cum manu tua altera ab interiori parte ossis decenter, et cum eo aequa ipsam.	 If the fracture is on the right side of the bone, you must insert your left index finger into the diseased jaw: Similarly, if the fracture is in the left jaw, then insert your right index finger: And push the swelling of the fracture gently towards the outside with your other hand properly from the inside part of the bone and with it, equalize it.
Quod si fractura mandibulae iam separata est in duo, tunc oportet, ut administres extersionem a duabus partibus, secundum rectitudinem: donec possibilis sit aequatio eius.	 If the fracture of the jaw is already separated into two parts, then it is necessary to apply traction from both sides according to correctness until its alignment is possible.
Si autem iam accidit in dentibus commotio, aut disruptio: tunc stringe illos de quibus speras quod remaneant cum filo auri, aut argenti, aut seta.	 But if already there is movement or disruption of the teeth, then bind those which you hope remain with a thread of gold, silver or silk.
Deinde pone super mandibulam fractam caerotum.	 Then place on the broken jaw a piece of raw hide.
Deinde pone super ipsum pannum duplicatum, et pone super pannum astellam magnam decenter factam: aut frustum cutis soleae aequale, in longitudinem mandibulae.	 Then place over it a double cloth and put on the large cross made well over it or an equal piece of shoe leather, in length of the jawbone.
Deinde liga ipsum desuper, secundum quod praeparatur tibi ligatura eius, et conuenit ipsius applicatio, donec non destruitur: et praecipe infirmo, uti tranquillitate et quiete: et pone cibum eius sorbitiones lenes.	 Then bind it above as your binding for it is ready and its application is suitable until it does not break: And instruct the sick man to rest calmly and quietly: And put his food in mild broths.
Si autem estimas, quod iam alteratur aliquid figurae aliquo modorum: tunc propera, et solue ipsum in die tertio.	 If you estimate that something has changed in its shape in some way: Then hasten and cut it open on the third day.
Deinde rectifica quod alteratum est ex eo, et emplastra ipsum ex puluere molendini, cum albugine oui, aut cum farina sisami, postquam tu abstuleris caerotum: et pone super emplastrum lanam lenem.	 Then adjust what has changed from it, and cover it with plaster from milled flour mixed with egg white or wheat flour, after you have removed the raw hide: And put over the plaster a soft wool.
Dum ergo permanet annexum illud emplastrum super ipsum, et non alteratur ossis dispositio, dimitte ipsum, ne soluas, donec sanetur: aut stringe fracturam.	 While that adhesive plaster remains on it, and the bone arrangement does not change, leave it be without removing it until it heals; or bind the fracture.
Multotiens enim stringitur haec fractura in tribus septimanis.	 This fracture is often bound for three weeks.
Quod si interim accidat apostema calidum, tunc administra illud quod diximus multotiens in sedatione eius, donec remoueatur illud apostema.	 If a warm boil occurs in the meantime, then administer what I have said repeatedly for its reduction until that boil is removed.
Et si fractura est cum uulnere, considera.	 And if the fracture is with a wound, consider it.
Namsi iam separatur ex osse frustum, aut a satagie: tunc subtilia te in hoc, ut auferas illa frusta satagiae cum eo quod conuenit tibi in ablatione eorum ex instrumentis.	 If a piece of bone is already separated from the bone or from a tendon, then be subtle about it, to remove those pieces of tendon along with whatever suits you for their removal from the instruments.
Si uero orificium uulneris est strictum, tunc amplifica ipsum cum phlebotomo secundum quantitatem necessitatis tuae.	 If the wound opening is narrow, then enlarge it with a leech according to your need.
Deinde quando abstuleris illa satagie, et non remanserit ex eis aliquid, sue tunc orificium uulneris, si est amplum: et si non, pone super ipsum ex emplastris quae conueniunt ad illud, et incarnant illud, donec sanetur.	 Then when you have removed the tendon pieces, and there remains nothing of them, or if the wound opening is wide: and if not, place on it ointments that suit for that, and let it heal until it heals.
¶ De restauratione Furculae, quando frangitur.	 Chapter on the restoration of the Fork (when it breaks).
Caput VI.	 Chapter VI.
Plurimum quidem frangitur Furcula ab anteriore parte ex parte humeri, et fractura eius fit secundum unum trium modorum.	 The fork is broken most frequently from the anterior part of the shoulder, and its breakage occurs in one of three modes.
Aut enim frangitur et separatur in duo, praeter quod accidant in ea satagiae: et est facilius ad restaurationem eius.	 Or it breaks into two parts, with tendons possibly involved: and this is easier for its restoration.
Aut ita, quod accidunt in osse satagiae: et est difficilius ad restaurationem.	 Or it happens so that there are pieces of bone involved: and this is more difficult to restore.
Aut ita, quod est fractura cum uulnere.	 Or it is a break with a wound.
Et operatio in ea quando fractura est absque uulnere, est, ut facias praesentes esse duos ministros, ut teneat unus eorum adiutorium quod sequitur Furculam fractam, et alter extendat collum uersus partem.	 And the operation in this case when the break is without a wound is that you have two assistants present, one holds the limb with the broken fork, and the other extends the neck toward the opposite side.
Deinde aequa fracturam digitis tuis, donec fiat forma eius, secundum quod oportet: et non sit in ea eminentia, neque concauitas.	 Then you should align the broken part with your fingers until its shape is correct; and there should be neither a projection nor a hollow.
Quod si indiges extensione plus, tunc oportet, ut ponas sub titillico infirmi spheram ex panno, aut lana: et sit magnitudo eius secundum quantitatem necessitatis tuae: et extende, et eleua Furculam, et coarta spheram manu tua, donec aeques fracturam, secundum quod oportet.	 If you require more extension, then it is necessary that you place under the patient's wound sphere made of cloth or wool; and let its size be according to your need; stretch and elevate the lever, and compress the sphere with your hand until it equals the fracture, as needed.
Quod si non potes trahere extremitatem Furculae ad exteriora: propterea, quia peruenit ad profundum: tunc oportet, ut resupinetur infirmus super ceruicem suam: et ponas sub humero eius puluinar medium in magnitudine, et premat minister humerum eius ad inferiora, donec eleuetur os Furculae quod est in profundo ad sursum: atque tunc rectifica fracturam, et aequa eam digitis tuis.	 If you cannot pull the extremity of the lever outside: because it has reached deep: then it is necessary that the patient lies on his neck; and place under his shoulder a saw medium in size, and press the minister of his shoulder towards the lower part, until the bone of the lever that is in the depth rises upwards: and then correct the fracture, and make it even with your fingers.
Si autem sentis sathaiatum ex Furcula, et mouetur: tunc oportet, ut findas super illud, et extrahas ipsum alsathaiatum cum facilitate.	 If however you feel a splinter from the lever and it moves: then it is necessary that you probe over it, and remove the splinter with ease.
Si autem est retentum in osse, tunc ingenia in incisione eius cum uno Incisoriorum quae praeparasti ad illud, postquam tu posueris sub Furcula instrumentum quod seruat sifach: et est instrumentum ex ligno, aut ex ferro.	 If however it is retained in the bone, then apply an instrument of incision that you have prepared for this purpose, after you place under the lever a tool which saves silk: and the tool is made of wood or iron.
Et haec est forma eius.	 And this is its shape.
Assimilatur cochleari cui non est concauitas.	 It resembles a snail shell without a hollow.
Et sit latitudo eius secundum illud quo indiges eo ex magnitudine ossis, et paruitate eius.	 And let its width be according to the bone you need it for and its size.
Longitudo uero eius etiam secundum quod possibile est tibi ad operationem.	 The length of it also, as far as possible for your operation.
Et habeat duas extremitates, sicut uides: et extremitas una sit ampla, et altera stricta.	 And have two ends, as you see: and one end should be broad, and the other narrow.
Si autem disruptio uulneris quod scidisti quando extraxisti sathaiatum ossis, est ampla, et securaris ab apostemate calido: tunc aggrega duo labia uulneris cum sutura.	 If however the wound which you have cut when you remove the splinter of bone is wide and gaping, and sews itself with hot cautery: then join together two lips of the wound with stitching.
Et si disruptio est parua, aut times apostema calidum: tunc imple uulnus cum pannis, et puluillis secundum quantitatem scissurae uulneris.	 And if the wound is small or you fear hot cautery: then fill the wound with cloths and wool according to the size of the wound cut.
Quod si accidat apostema calidum, tunc infunde pannum in oleo rosato, et aceto, et uino, et pone super ipsum.	 If a hot abscess occurs, then soak a cloth in rose oil, vinegar, and wine, and place it on top of it.
Strictura uero ossis quando est absque uulnere, et absque sectione, est, ut ponas super os emplastrum factum ex farina molendini cum albugine oui.	 However, if the bone is constricted without a wound and without incision, it should be covered with a plaster made from milled flour with egg white.
Et pone stuppam lenem super ipsum.	 And place soft wool on top of it.
Deinde pone spheram sub titillico eius, si indiges illa.	 Then put a small ball under its pulsation, if needed.
Deinde accipe himematem, id est, rotam quam tenent Saraceni, quae sit longa ualde: et sit latitudo eius palmi unius, aut circiter illud.	 Then take a bloodletting instrument, that is the rotula which the Saracens hold, which should be very long; and its width should be one palm or approximately that.
Deinde pone puluillum duplicatum super stuppam et emplastrum.	 Then place a folded piece of wool over the soft wool and the plaster.
Deinde accipe astellam ex tabula subtili, cuius latitudo sit trium digitorum, et in longitudine similiter.	 Then take an awl from a thin board, whose width is three fingers, and similarly in length.
Deinde inuolue eam in panno.	 Then fold it into the cloth.
Deinde inuolue pannum illum cum astella in loco alhimemati qui cadit super fracturam et locum.	 Then fold the cloth with the awl into the place of the incision over the fracture and the site.
Deinde pone alhimemati super fracturam sicut reuoluiur, et inuolue eam super collum eius, et sub titillico eius sano, et sub titillico eius infirmo: et reduc eam super omnem partem, et quomodo uides quod strictura tenet fracturam strictura decenti: et est illud, quod non occultatur super te, et totum, ut non remoueatur astella desuper os fractum.	 Then apply the incision to the fracture as it is described, and fold it over the neck of the healthy side and the weak side, and under the pulsation of the healthy side and the sick side: and bring it over the entire part, so that it is clear to you how the constriction holds the fracture correctly: and this should not be hidden from you, and all of it, so that the awl does not remove the fractured bone.
Et propter hoc oportet, ut aspicias infirmum in omni die.	 And for this reason, it is necessary to examine the sick side every day.
Quotiens ergo mollificatur ligamentum, et uides astellam iam remoueri: tunc rectifica illud, et stringe ligamentum.	 When does the ligament soften and you see that the awl has already been removed? Then adjust it, and tighten the ligament.
Deinde pone somnum infirmi super dorsum eius, et pone sub titillico eius apud somnum eius puluinar paruum in nocte, ut cum eo eleuetur adiutorium eius a latere ipsius.	 Then place the sick person's sleep on his back, and put a small pillow under its pulsation near its sleep at night, so that when it rises, help comes to its side.
Eleuatur ergo fractura furculae per eleuationem humeri.	 Lift therefore the fracture of the clavicle by lifting the humerus.
Aut liga brachium eius ad collum ipsius: et non soluas ligamentum, si non accidat in loco accidens ex pruritu, aut ab apostemate, usque ad duodecim dies.	 Tie the arm to his neck; do not loosen the bandage unless it happens due to an incident caused by itching or abscess, for twelve days.
Deinde renoua emplastrum, si uideris faciem eius ad illud.	 Then renew the plaster if you see his face towards that (the affected area).
Et adde in strictura, et dimitte ipsum, donec restauretur et coaguletur.	 And add to the constriction, and let it be, until it is restored and hardened.
Et fractura quidem furculae stringitur et confortatur secundum plurimum in uigintiocto diebus: et quandoque fit in quibusdam hominibus in minore illo.	 The fracture of the clavicle is bound and supported as much as possible for twenty-eight days; sometimes it heals more quickly in some people.
¶ De restauratione fracturae Spatulae.	 Chapter on the restoration of the fracture of the spatula (scapula).
Caput VII.	 Chapter VII.
Raro frangitur Spatula, et in loco lato eius: et non franguntur ex ea nisi margines eius.	 The spatula is seldom broken, and at its wide end: and it is not broken from anything except its edges.
Quando ergo frangitur ex eo locus, et frangitur in medio eius, et non cognoscitur illud nisi per tactum: tunc secundum quod est figura fracturae conare praeparationem eius.	 When it is broken from that place, and it is broken in the middle of it, and it is not recognized except by touch, then according to its figure prepare the treatment for it.
Et reduc eam super figuram naturalem omni modo ingenii, quod est tibi possibile.	 And reduce it to its natural form by any means of your intellect that is possible for you.
Deinde pone super locum puluerem molendini cum albugine oui, et stuppam lenem, et pone desuper puluillum ex panno duplato.	 Then place upon it powder of millstone with egg white, and soft starch, and place on top a small piece of double cloth.
Deinde pone super ipsum astellam latam ex tabula subtili secundum quantitatem Spatulae totius, aut ampliorem ea parum.	 Then place upon it a broad awl from thin wood according to the quantity of the spatula or larger by little.
Si uero sub astella est concauitas in aliquo locorum Spatulae, tunc aequa illam concauitatem cum stuppa leni, donec descendat astella secundum aequalitatem.	 If however there is a depression under the awl at any part of the spatula, then fill that depression with soft starch until the awl descends according to its equal level.
Deinde ftringe desuper cum alhimemati longa, constrictione decenti, et firmitudine astellae, donec non remoueatur a loco suo.	 Then bind on top with long alum thread in an appropriate constriction and the firmness of the awl until it is not moved from its place.
Et considera ligamentum in omni die.	 And consider the binding every day.
Quotienscunque ergo mollificatur ligamentum, stringe ipsum, et aequa astellam si remoueatur a loco suo: et iaceat infirmus super latus suum sanum.	 Whenever therefore the binding becomes soft, bind it again, and if the awl is moved from its place, let it lie weak on its healthy side.
Et Spatula quidem restauratur in uiginti diebus, aut in uigintiquinque diebus.	 And the spatula certainly recovers in twenty days or forty days.
Quando ergo completur iste numerus, tunc solue ligamentum: et tu sis in securitate.	 When this number is complete, then loosen the binding: and you will be secure.
Nam ipsa est ex ossibus quorum communitio non timetur, neque eorum solutio.	 For it is made from bones whose breakage is not feared nor their solution.
Si autem procedat ex osse frustum, et pungit sub cute: tune scinde super ipsum, et aufer ipsum.	 If however a fragment of bone protrudes and pierces under the skin, then cut through it, and remove it.
Et fac quod diximus in fractura furculae ex sedatione apostematis calidi, si accidat ex eo aliquid.	 And do as we said in the fracture of a collarbone from cauterization by hot metal, if something happens from it.
¶ De restauratione fracturae Pectoris.	 § On the restoration of a breast fracture.
Caput VIII.	 Head VIII.
Pectus quandoque frangitur in medio sui, et raro accidit illud.	 Chest occasionally breaks in the middle of itself, and it happens rarely.
Extremitates eius quidem plurimum franguntur, et comminuuntur ex accidentibus eius.	 Its extremities indeed break more often than the chest itself does, due to its accidents.
Quando frangitur eius medium, quod declinat ad inferiora, et accidit ei dolor uehemens, et difficultas in anhelitu, et tussis: et fortasse euomit sanguinem, et declaratur concauitas in osse fracto, et non occultatur sensui, Restauratio eius est, ut resupinetur infirmus super dorsum suum: et pone inter Spatulas eius puluinar.	 When the middle of it breaks down and tends towards the lower parts, it causes a very strong pain, difficulty in breathing, coughing, perhaps vomiting blood, and a hollow appears in the fractured bone that is not concealed to the sense; The restoration of this is to lay the weak one on his back, and place between his shoulders a poultice.
Deinde preme humeros eius, et aggrega costas a duabus partibus uel lateribus cum manibus: et subtiliare in aequatione eius, secundum omnem modum quo possibile est illud et conuenit, donec redeat figura ossis, secundum quod oportet.
